<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-San_Francisco skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">San Francisco</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:About&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:About (page does not exist)">Template:About</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Use_mdy_dates&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Use mdy dates (page does not exist)">Template:Use mdy dates</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-move-indef&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-move-indef (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-move-indef</a>
{{#invoke:Infobox|infobox}}
</p><p><b>San Francisco</b> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPAc-en&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPAc-en (page does not exist)">Template:IPAc-en</a>, officially the <b>City and County of San Francisco</b>, is the leading financial and cultural center of <a href="/wiki/Northern_California" title="Northern California">Northern California</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=San_Francisco_Bay_Area&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San Francisco Bay Area (page does not exist)">San Francisco Bay Area</a>.
</p><p>The only <a href="/w/index.php?title=Consolidated_city%E2%80%93county&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Consolidated city–county (page does not exist)">consolidated city-county</a> in <a href="/wiki/California" title="California">California</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-CityCounty_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CityCounty-1">[1]</a></sup> San Francisco encompasses a land area of about <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a><sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup> on the northern end of the <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Peninsula" title="San Francisco Peninsula">San Francisco Peninsula</a>, giving it a density of about 17,620 people per square mile (6,803 people per km<sup>2</sup>). It is the most densely settled large city (population greater than 200,000) in the state of California and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_United_States_cities_by_population_density&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of United States cities by population density (page does not exist)">second-most densely populated</a> major city in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States (page does not exist)">United States</a> after <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-SF_Population_Density_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SF_Population_Density-3">[3]</a></sup> San Francisco is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_cities_in_California_(by_population)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of cities in California (by population) (page does not exist)">fourth most populous city</a> in California, after <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">Los Angeles</a>, <a href="/wiki/San_Diego" title="San Diego">San Diego</a> and <a href="/wiki/San_Jose,_California" title="San Jose, California">San Jose</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_United_States_cities_by_population" title="List of United States cities by population">14th most populous city</a> in the United States—with a Census-estimated 2012 population of 825,863.<sup id="cite_ref-2012-pop-estimate_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2012-pop-estimate-4">[4]</a></sup> The city is also the financial and cultural hub of the larger <a href="/w/index.php?title=San_Francisco_Bay_Area_Combined_Statistical_Area&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San Francisco Bay Area Combined Statistical Area (page does not exist)">San Jose-San Francisco-Oakland</a> combined statistical area, with a population of 8.4 million.
</p><p>San Francisco (Spanish for "Saint Francis") was founded on June 29, 1776, when <a href="/wiki/Spanish_colonization_of_the_Americas" title="Spanish colonization of the Americas">colonists from Spain</a> established <a href="/wiki/Presidio_of_San_Francisco" title="Presidio of San Francisco">a fort</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Gate" title="Golden Gate">Golden Gate</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mission_San_Francisco_de_As%C3%ADs" title="Mission San Francisco de Asís">a mission</a> named for <a href="/wiki/St._Francis_of_Assisi" title="St. Francis of Assisi" class="mw-redirect">St. Francis of Assisi</a> a few miles away.<sup id="cite_ref-DeAnza-Moraga-Palou_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DeAnza-Moraga-Palou-5">[5]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/California_Gold_Rush" title="California Gold Rush">California Gold Rush</a> of 1849 brought rapid growth, making it the largest city on the <a href="/wiki/West_Coast_of_the_United_States" title="West Coast of the United States">West Coast</a> at the time. Due to the growth of its population, San Francisco became a consolidated city-county in 1856.<sup id="cite_ref-Coy_1919_409_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Coy_1919_409-6">[6]</a></sup>
After three-quarters of the city was destroyed by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=1906_San_Francisco_earthquake&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="1906 San Francisco earthquake (page does not exist)">1906 earthquake and fire</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Montagne_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Montagne-7">[7]</a></sup> San Francisco was quickly rebuilt, hosting the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Panama-Pacific_International_Exposition_(1915)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Panama-Pacific International Exposition (1915) (page does not exist)">Panama-Pacific International Exposition</a> nine years later. During <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, San Francisco was the port of embarkation for service members shipping out to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pacific_Ocean_theater_of_World_War_II&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pacific Ocean theater of World War II (page does not exist)">Pacific Theater</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-WWII_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WWII-8">[8]</a></sup> After the war, the confluence of returning servicemen, massive <a href="/w/index.php?title=Immigration&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Immigration (page does not exist)">immigration</a>, liberalizing attitudes, and other factors led to the <a href="/wiki/Summer_of_Love" title="Summer of Love">Summer of Love</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=LGBT_rights_in_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="LGBT rights in the United States (page does not exist)">gay rights</a> movement, cementing San Francisco as a center of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Modern_liberalism_in_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Modern liberalism in the United States (page does not exist)">liberal activism in the United States</a>.
</p><p>Today, San Francisco is ranked 44th of the top tourist destinations in the world,<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup> and was the sixth most visited one in the United States in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup> The city is renowned for its cool summers, fog, steep rolling hills, <a href="/w/index.php?title=San_Francisco_architecture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San Francisco architecture (page does not exist)">eclectic mix of architecture</a>, and landmarks including the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Gate_Bridge" title="Golden Gate Bridge">Golden Gate Bridge</a>, <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_cable_car_system" title="San Francisco cable car system">cable cars</a>, the former <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alcatraz_Federal_Penitentiary&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alcatraz Federal Penitentiary (page does not exist)">prison</a> on <a href="/wiki/Alcatraz_Island" title="Alcatraz Island">Alcatraz Island</a>, and its <a href="/wiki/Chinatown,_San_Francisco" title="Chinatown, San Francisco">Chinatown</a> district. It is also a primary banking and finance center.
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="quotebox" style="float: left; clear: left; margin: 0.5em 1.4em 0.8em 0; width: 18.75em; padding: 6px; border: 1px solid #aaa; font-size: 90%; background-color: #B0C4DE;">
<div style="background: #B0C4DE; color:black; text-align: center; font-size: larger; font-weight: bold;">Historical Affiliations</div>
<div style="position: relative; text-align: left;">
<div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">Spanish Empire</a> 1776–1821<br />
<a href="/wiki/First_Mexican_Empire" title="First Mexican Empire">First Mexican Empire</a> 1821–1823<br />
<a href="/wiki/United_Mexican_States" title="United Mexican States" class="mw-redirect">United Mexican States</a> 1823–1848<br />
<a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States (page does not exist)">United States</a> 1848–present
</p>
</div>
</div>
<div style="text-align: left;"> </div>
</div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Mission_San_Francisco_de_Asis_old.jpg" title="File:Mission San Francisco de Asis old.jpg">File:Mission San Francisco de Asis old.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Mission_San_Francisco_de_As%C3%ADs" title="Mission San Francisco de Asís">Mission San Francisco de Asís</a> (Mission Dolores)</div></div></div>The earliest archaeological evidence of human habitation of the territory of the city of San Francisco dates to 3000&#160;BC.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yelamu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yelamu (page does not exist)">Yelamu</a> group of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ohlone&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ohlone (page does not exist)">Ohlone</a> people resided in a few small villages when an overland <a href="/wiki/Spanish_colonization_of_the_Americas" title="Spanish colonization of the Americas">Spanish exploration party</a>, led by Don <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gaspar_de_Portol%C3%A0&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gaspar de Portolà (page does not exist)">Gaspar de Portolà</a> arrived on November 2, 1769, the first documented European visit to <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Bay" title="San Francisco Bay">San Francisco Bay</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Portola_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Portola-12">[12]</a></sup> Seven years later, on March 28, 1776, the Spanish established the <a href="/wiki/Presidio_of_San_Francisco" title="Presidio of San Francisco">Presidio of San Francisco</a>, followed by a <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Missions_of_California" title="Spanish Missions of California" class="mw-redirect">mission</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mission_San_Francisco_de_As%C3%ADs" title="Mission San Francisco de Asís">Mission San Francisco de Asís</a> (Mission Dolores), established by the <a href="/wiki/New_Spain" title="New Spain">Novo-Spanish</a> explorer <a href="/wiki/Juan_Bautista_de_Anza" title="Juan Bautista de Anza">Juan Bautista de Anza</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-DeAnza-Moraga-Palou_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DeAnza-Moraga-Palou-5">[5]</a></sup>
<p>Upon <a href="/wiki/Mexican_War_of_Independence" title="Mexican War of Independence">independence</a> from Spain in 1821, the area became part of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mexico (page does not exist)">Mexico</a>. Under Mexican rule, the mission system gradually ended, and its lands became <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ranchos_of_California&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ranchos of California (page does not exist)">privatized</a>. In 1835, Englishman <a href="/w/index.php?title=William_A._Richardson&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="William A. Richardson (page does not exist)">William Richardson</a> erected the first independent homestead,<sup id="cite_ref-Richardson_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Richardson-13">[13]</a></sup> near a boat anchorage around what is today <a href="/w/index.php?title=Portsmouth_Square&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Portsmouth Square (page does not exist)">Portsmouth Square</a>. Together with <a href="/wiki/Alcalde" title="Alcalde">Alcalde</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Francisco_de_Haro&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Francisco de Haro (page does not exist)">Francisco de Haro</a>, he laid out a street plan for the expanded settlement, and the town, named <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yerba_Buena,_California&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yerba Buena, California (page does not exist)">Yerba Buena</a>, began to attract American settlers. Commodore <a href="/wiki/John_D._Sloat" title="John D. Sloat">John D. Sloat</a> claimed California for the United States on July 7, 1846, during the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexican-American_War&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mexican-American War (page does not exist)">Mexican-American War</a>, and Captain <a href="/wiki/John_B._Montgomery" title="John B. Montgomery">John B. Montgomery</a> arrived to claim Yerba Buena two days later. Yerba Buena was renamed San Francisco on January 30 of the next year,<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup> and Mexico officially <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Cession" title="Mexican Cession">ceded the territory</a> to the United States at the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Guadalupe-Hidalgo" title="Treaty of Guadalupe-Hidalgo" class="mw-redirect">end of the war</a>. Despite its attractive location as a port and naval base, San Francisco was still a small settlement with inhospitable geography.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:SanFrancisco1851a.jpg" title="File:SanFrancisco1851a.jpg">File:SanFrancisco1851a.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Portsmouth_Square&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Portsmouth Square (page does not exist)">Portsmouth Square</a> in 1851</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:SanFranciscoharbor1851c_sharp.jpg" title="File:SanFranciscoharbor1851c sharp.jpg">File:SanFranciscoharbor1851c sharp.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Port_of_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Port of San Francisco (page does not exist)">Port of San Francisco</a> in 1851</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/California_Gold_Rush" title="California Gold Rush">California Gold Rush</a> brought a flood of treasure seekers. With their <a href="/wiki/Sourdough" title="Sourdough">sourdough bread</a> in tow,<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> prospectors accumulated in San Francisco over rival <a href="/wiki/Benicia,_California" title="Benicia, California">Benicia</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup> raising the population from 1,000 in 1848 to 25,000 by December 1849.<sup id="cite_ref-1849pop_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1849pop-18">[18]</a></sup> The promise of fabulous riches was so strong that crews on arriving vessels deserted and rushed off to the gold fields, leaving behind a forest of masts in San Francisco harbor.<sup id="cite_ref-buriedships_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-buriedships-19">[19]</a></sup> California was quickly <a href="/wiki/Compromise_of_1850" title="Compromise of 1850">granted statehood</a>, and the U.S. military built <a href="/wiki/Fort_Point,_San_Francisco" title="Fort Point, San Francisco">Fort Point</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Gate" title="Golden Gate">Golden Gate</a> and a fort on <a href="/wiki/Alcatraz_Island" title="Alcatraz Island">Alcatraz Island</a> to secure the San Francisco Bay. Silver discoveries, including the <a href="/wiki/Comstock_Lode" title="Comstock Lode">Comstock Lode</a> in 1859, further drove rapid population growth.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup> With hordes of fortune seekers streaming through the city, lawlessness was common, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Barbary_Coast,_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Barbary Coast, San Francisco (page does not exist)">Barbary Coast</a> section of town gained notoriety as a haven for criminals, prostitution, and gambling.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup>
</p><p>Entrepreneurs sought to capitalize on the wealth generated by the Gold Rush. Early winners were the banking industry, with the founding of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wells_Fargo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wells Fargo (page does not exist)">Wells Fargo</a> in 1852 and the <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_California" title="Bank of California">Bank of California</a> in 1864. Development of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Port_of_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Port of San Francisco (page does not exist)">Port of San Francisco</a> and the establishment in 1869 of overland access to the Eastern U.S. rail system via the newly completed <a href="/wiki/First_Transcontinental_Railroad" title="First Transcontinental Railroad">Pacific Railroad</a> (the construction of which the city only reluctantly helped support<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup>) helped make the Bay Area a center for trade. Catering to the needs and tastes of the growing population, <a href="/wiki/Levi_Strauss" title="Levi Strauss">Levi Strauss</a> opened a dry goods business and <a href="/wiki/Domingo_Ghirardelli" title="Domingo Ghirardelli">Domingo Ghirardelli</a> began manufacturing chocolate. Immigrant laborers made the city a polyglot culture, with <a href="/wiki/Han_Chinese" title="Han Chinese">Chinese</a> railroad workers creating the city's <a href="/wiki/Chinatown,_San_Francisco" title="Chinatown, San Francisco">Chinatown</a> quarter. In 1870, Asians made up 8% of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-census_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-census-23">[23]</a></sup> The first <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_cable_car_system" title="San Francisco cable car system">cable cars</a> carried San Franciscans up <a href="/wiki/Clay_Street_Hill_Railroad" title="Clay Street Hill Railroad">Clay Street</a> in 1873. The city's sea of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Victorian_house&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Victorian house (page does not exist)">Victorian houses</a> began to take shape, and civic leaders campaigned for a spacious public park, resulting in plans for <a href="/wiki/Golden_Gate_Park" title="Golden Gate Park">Golden Gate Park</a>. San Franciscans built schools, churches, theaters, and all the hallmarks of civic life. The <a href="/wiki/Presidio_of_San_Francisco" title="Presidio of San Francisco">Presidio</a> developed into the most important American military installation on the Pacific coast.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup> By 1890, San Francisco's population approached 300,000, making it the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Largest_cities_in_the_United_States_by_population_by_decade&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Largest cities in the United States by population by decade (page does not exist)">eighth largest city</a> in the U.S. at the time. Around 1901, San Francisco was a major city known for its flamboyant style, stately hotels, ostentatious mansions on <a href="/wiki/Nob_Hill,_San_Francisco" title="Nob Hill, San Francisco">Nob Hill</a>, and a thriving arts scene.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup> The first North American plague epidemic was the <a href="/w/index.php?title=San_Francisco_plague_of_1900%E2%80%931904&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San Francisco plague of 1900–1904 (page does not exist)">San Francisco plague of 1900–1904</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Wide_image&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Wide image (page does not exist)">Template:Wide image</a>
</p><p>At 5:12&#160;am on April 18, 1906, a major <a href="/w/index.php?title=1906_San_Francisco_earthquake&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="1906 San Francisco earthquake (page does not exist)">earthquake struck San Francisco</a> and northern California. As buildings collapsed from the shaking, ruptured gas lines ignited fires that spread across the city and burned out of control for several days. With water mains out of service, the <a href="/wiki/Presidio_of_San_Francisco" title="Presidio of San Francisco">Presidio</a> Artillery Corps attempted to contain the inferno by dynamiting blocks of buildings to create firebreaks.<sup id="cite_ref-Funston_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Funston-27">[27]</a></sup> More than three-quarters of the city lay in ruins, including almost all of the downtown core.<sup id="cite_ref-Montagne_7-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Montagne-7">[7]</a></sup> Contemporary accounts reported that 498 people lost their lives, though modern estimates put the number in the several thousands.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup> More than half the city's population of 400,000 were left homeless.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup> Refugees settled temporarily in makeshift tent villages in Golden Gate Park, the Presidio, on the beaches, and elsewhere. Many fled permanently to the <a href="/wiki/East_Bay_(San_Francisco_Bay_Area)" title="East Bay (San Francisco Bay Area)">East Bay</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:PalaceofFineArts1915.jpg" title="File:PalaceofFineArts1915.jpg">File:PalaceofFineArts1915.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Palace_of_Fine_Arts" title="Palace of Fine Arts">Palace of Fine Arts</a> at the 1915 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Panama-Pacific_International_Exposition_(1915)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Panama-Pacific International Exposition (1915) (page does not exist)">Panama-Pacific Exposition</a></div></div></div>
<p>Rebuilding was rapid and performed on a grand scale. Rejecting calls to completely remake the street grid, San Franciscans opted for speed.<sup id="cite_ref-NatTrust1_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NatTrust1-30">[30]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amadeo_Giannini&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Amadeo Giannini (page does not exist)">Amadeo Giannini</a>'s <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_Italy_(USA)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bank of Italy (USA) (page does not exist)">Bank of Italy</a>, later to become <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_America" title="Bank of America">Bank of America</a>, provided loans for many of those whose livelihoods had been devastated. The influential <a href="/w/index.php?title=San_Francisco_Planning_and_Urban_Research_Association&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San Francisco Planning and Urban Research Association (page does not exist)">San Francisco Planning and Urban Research Association</a> or SPUR was founded in 1910 to address the quality of housing after the earthquake.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup> The earthquake hastened development of western neighborhoods that survived the fire, including <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Heights,_San_Francisco" title="Pacific Heights, San Francisco">Pacific Heights</a>, where many of the city's wealthy rebuilt their homes.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> In turn, the destroyed mansions of Nob Hill became grand hotels. <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_City_Hall" title="San Francisco City Hall">City Hall</a> rose again in splendorous <a href="/wiki/Beaux-Arts_architecture" title="Beaux-Arts architecture">Beaux Arts</a> style, and the city celebrated its rebirth at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Panama-Pacific_International_Exposition_(1915)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Panama-Pacific International Exposition (1915) (page does not exist)">Panama-Pacific International Exposition</a> in 1915.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup>
</p><p>It was during this period San Francisco built some of its most important infrastructure. Civil Engineer <a href="/w/index.php?title=Michael_O%27Shaughnessy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Michael O'Shaughnessy (page does not exist)">Michael O'Shaughnessy</a> was hired by San Francisco Mayor <a href="/wiki/James_Rolph" title="James Rolph">James Rolph</a> as chief engineer for the city in September 1912 to supervise the construction of the Twin Peaks Reservoir, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Stockton_Street_Tunnel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Stockton Street Tunnel (page does not exist)">Stockton Street Tunnel</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Twin_Peaks_Tunnel" title="Twin Peaks Tunnel">Twin Peaks Tunnel</a>, the <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Municipal_Railway" title="San Francisco Municipal Railway">San Francisco Municipal Railway</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=San_Francisco_Fire_Department_Auxiliary_Water_Supply_System&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San Francisco Fire Department Auxiliary Water Supply System (page does not exist)">Auxiliary Water Supply System</a>, and new sewers. San Francisco's streetcar system, of which the J, K, L, M, and N lines survive today, was pushed to completion by O'Shaughnessy between 1915 and 1927. It was the <a href="/wiki/Hetch_Hetchy" title="Hetch Hetchy">O'Shaughnessy Dam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hetch_Hetchy_Reservoir" title="Hetch Hetchy Reservoir" class="mw-redirect">Hetch Hetchy Reservoir</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hetch_Hetchy_Aqueduct&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hetch Hetchy Aqueduct (page does not exist)">Hetch Hetchy Aqueduct</a> that would have the largest effect on San Francisco.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup> An abundant water supply enabled San Francisco to develop into the city it has become today.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:SF-Oakland-Bay-Bridge-Construction.jpg" title="File:SF-Oakland-Bay-Bridge-Construction.jpg">File:SF-Oakland-Bay-Bridge-Construction.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco%E2%80%93Oakland_Bay_Bridge" title="San Francisco–Oakland Bay Bridge">Bay Bridge</a>, under construction in 1935, took forty months to complete.</div></div></div>
<p>In ensuing years, the city solidified its standing as a financial capital; in the wake of the <a href="/wiki/Wall_Street_Crash_of_1929" title="Wall Street Crash of 1929">1929 stock market crash</a>, not a single San Francisco-based bank failed.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup> Indeed, it was at the height of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Great_Depression&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Great Depression (page does not exist)">Great Depression</a> that San Francisco undertook two great civil engineering projects, simultaneously constructing the <a href="/w/index.php?title=San_Francisco_%E2%80%93_Oakland_Bay_Bridge&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San Francisco – Oakland Bay Bridge (page does not exist)">San Francisco – Oakland Bay Bridge</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Gate_Bridge" title="Golden Gate Bridge">Golden Gate Bridge</a>, completing them in 1936 and 1937 respectively. It was in this period that the island of <a href="/wiki/Alcatraz_Island" title="Alcatraz Island">Alcatraz</a>, a former military stockade, began its service as a federal maximum security prison, housing notorious inmates such as <a href="/wiki/Al_Capone" title="Al Capone">Al Capone</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Robert_Franklin_Stroud&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Robert Franklin Stroud (page does not exist)">Robert Franklin Stroud</a>, The Birdman of Alcatraz. San Francisco later celebrated its regained grandeur with a <a href="/wiki/World%27s_fair" title="World's fair">World's Fair</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Golden_Gate_International_Exposition&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Golden Gate International Exposition (page does not exist)">Golden Gate International Exposition</a> in 1939–40, creating <a href="/w/index.php?title=Treasure_Island_(California)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Treasure Island (California) (page does not exist)">Treasure Island</a> in the middle of the bay to house it.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:USS_San_Francisco_(CA-38)_enters_San_Francisco_Bay,_December_1942.jpg" title="File:USS San Francisco (CA-38) enters San Francisco Bay, December 1942.jpg">File:USS San Francisco (CA-38) enters San Francisco Bay, December 1942.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/USS_San_Francisco_(CA-38)" title="USS San Francisco (CA-38)">USS <i>San Francisco</i></a> steams under the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Gate_Bridge" title="Golden Gate Bridge">Golden Gate Bridge</a> in 1942, during World War&#160;II.</div></div></div>
<p>During World War II, the <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Naval_Shipyard" title="San Francisco Naval Shipyard">Hunters Point Naval Shipyard</a> became a hub of activity, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fort_Mason&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fort Mason (page does not exist)">Fort Mason</a> became the primary port of embarkation for service members shipping out to the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Theater_of_Operations" title="Pacific Theater of Operations">Pacific Theater of Operations</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-WWII_8-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WWII-8">[8]</a></sup> The explosion of jobs drew many people, especially African Americans <a href="/w/index.php?title=Second_Great_Migration_(African_American)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Second Great Migration (African American) (page does not exist)">from the South</a>, to the area. After the end of the war, many military personnel returning from service abroad and civilians who had originally come to work decided to stay. The <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Charter" title="United Nations Charter">UN Charter</a> creating the UN was drafted and signed in San Francisco in 1945 and, in 1951, the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_San_Francisco" title="Treaty of San Francisco">Treaty of San Francisco</a> officially ended the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_War" title="Pacific War">war with Japan</a>.
</p><p>Urban planning projects in the 1950s and 1960s involved widespread destruction and redevelopment of west-side neighborhoods and the construction of new freeways, of which only a series of short segments were built before being halted by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Freeway_and_expressway_revolts&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Freeway and expressway revolts (page does not exist)">citizen-led opposition</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup> The onset of <a href="/wiki/Containerization" title="Containerization">containerization</a> made San Francisco's small piers obsolete, and cargo activity moved to the larger <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Oakland" title="Port of Oakland">Port of Oakland</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup> The city began to lose industrial jobs and turned to tourism as the most important segment of its economy.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup> The suburbs experienced rapid growth, and San Francisco underwent significant demographic change, as large segments of the white population left the city, supplanted by an increasing wave of <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_the_United_States" title="Immigration to the United States">immigration</a> from Asia and Latin America.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup> From 1950 to 1980, the city lost over 10 percent of its population.
</p><p>Over this period, San Francisco became a magnet for America's counterculture. <a href="/wiki/Beat_Generation" title="Beat Generation">Beat Generation</a> writers fueled the <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Renaissance" title="San Francisco Renaissance">San Francisco Renaissance</a> and centered on the <a href="/wiki/North_Beach,_San_Francisco" title="North Beach, San Francisco">North Beach</a> neighborhood in the 1950s.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Hippie" title="Hippie">Hippies</a> flocked to <a href="/wiki/Haight-Ashbury" title="Haight-Ashbury">Haight-Ashbury</a> in the 1960s, reaching a peak with the 1967 <a href="/wiki/Summer_of_Love" title="Summer of Love">Summer of Love</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup> In 1974, the <a href="/wiki/Zebra_murders" title="Zebra murders">Zebra murders</a> left at least 16 people dead.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup> In the 1970s, the city became a center of the <a href="/wiki/LGBT_social_movements" title="LGBT social movements">gay rights movement</a>, with the emergence of <a href="/wiki/The_Castro,_San_Francisco" title="The Castro, San Francisco">The Castro</a> as an urban <a href="/wiki/Gay_village" title="Gay village">gay village</a>, the election of <a href="/wiki/Harvey_Milk" title="Harvey Milk">Harvey Milk</a> to the <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Board_of_Supervisors" title="San Francisco Board of Supervisors">Board of Supervisors</a>, and his <a href="/w/index.php?title=Moscone-Milk_assassinations&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Moscone-Milk assassinations (page does not exist)">assassination</a>, along with that of Mayor <a href="/wiki/George_Moscone" title="George Moscone">George Moscone</a>, in 1978.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup>
</p><p>Bank of America completed <a href="/wiki/555_California_Street" title="555 California Street">555 California Street</a> in 1969 and the <a href="/wiki/Transamerica_Pyramid" title="Transamerica Pyramid">Transamerica Pyramid</a> was completed in 1972,<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup> igniting a wave of "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Manhattanization&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Manhattanization (page does not exist)">Manhattanization</a>" that lasted until the late 1980s, a period of extensive high-rise development downtown.<sup id="cite_ref-NatTrust2_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NatTrust2-46">[46]</a></sup> The 1980s also saw a dramatic increase in the number of homeless people in the city, an issue that remains today, despite many attempts to address it.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup> The 1989 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Loma_Prieta_earthquake&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Loma Prieta earthquake (page does not exist)">Loma Prieta earthquake</a> caused destruction and loss of life throughout the Bay Area. In San Francisco, the quake severely damaged structures in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Marina_District,_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Marina District, San Francisco (page does not exist)">Marina</a> and <a href="/wiki/South_of_Market,_San_Francisco" title="South of Market, San Francisco">South of Market</a> districts and precipitated the demolition of the damaged <a href="/wiki/California_State_Route_480" title="California State Route 480">Embarcadero Freeway</a> and much of the damaged <a href="/wiki/Central_Freeway" title="Central Freeway">Central Freeway</a>, allowing the city to reclaim its historic downtown waterfront and revitalizing the <a href="/wiki/Hayes_Valley,_San_Francisco" title="Hayes Valley, San Francisco">Hayes Valley</a> neighborhood.
</p><p>During the <a href="/wiki/Dot-com_bubble" title="Dot-com bubble">dot-com boom</a> of the late 1990s, <a href="/wiki/Startup_company" title="Startup company">startup companies</a> invigorated the economy. Large numbers of entrepreneurs and computer application developers moved into the city, followed by marketing, design, and sales professionals, changing the social landscape as once-poorer neighborhoods became increasingly <a href="/wiki/Gentrification" title="Gentrification">gentrified</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup> Demand for new housing and office space ignited a second wave of high-rise development, this time South of Market.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> By 2000, the city's population reached new highs, surpassing the previous record set in 1950. When the bubble burst in 2001, many of these companies folded and their employees were laid off. Yet high technology and entrepreneurship remain mainstays of the San Francisco economy with the <a href="/wiki/Web_2.0" title="Web 2.0">social media boom</a> fueling growth in the second decade of the new century.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:SanFranciscoFromTheISS(Cropped).jpg" title="File:SanFranciscoFromTheISS(Cropped).jpg">File:SanFranciscoFromTheISS(Cropped).jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The San Francisco Peninsula</div></div></div>
<p>San Francisco is located on the <a href="/wiki/West_Coast_of_the_United_States" title="West Coast of the United States">West Coast of the United States</a> at the north end of the <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Peninsula" title="San Francisco Peninsula">San Francisco Peninsula</a> and includes significant stretches of the Pacific Ocean and <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Bay" title="San Francisco Bay">San Francisco Bay</a> within its boundaries. Several picturesque <a href="/w/index.php?title=Islands_of_San_Francisco_Bay&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Islands of San Francisco Bay (page does not exist)">islands</a>—<a href="/wiki/Alcatraz_Island" title="Alcatraz Island">Alcatraz</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Treasure_Island,_California&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Treasure Island, California (page does not exist)">Treasure Island</a> and the adjacent <a href="/wiki/Yerba_Buena_Island" title="Yerba Buena Island">Yerba Buena Island</a>, and small portions of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alameda_(island)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alameda (island) (page does not exist)">Alameda Island</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Red_Rock_Island&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Red Rock Island (page does not exist)">Red Rock Island</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Angel_Island,_California&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Angel Island, California (page does not exist)">Angel Island</a>—are part of the city. Also included are the uninhabited <a href="/wiki/Farallon_Islands" title="Farallon Islands">Farallon Islands</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> offshore in the Pacific Ocean. The mainland within the city limits roughly forms a "seven-by-seven-mile square," a common local colloquialism referring to the city's shape, though its total area, including water, is nearly <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Lombardst.jpeg" title="File:Lombardst.jpeg">File:Lombardst.jpeg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Cars navigate <a href="/wiki/Lombard_Street_(San_Francisco)" title="Lombard Street (San Francisco)">Lombard Street</a> to descend <a href="/wiki/Russian_Hill,_San_Francisco" title="Russian Hill, San Francisco">Russian Hill</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>San Francisco is famous for <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_hills_in_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of hills in San Francisco (page does not exist)">its hills</a>.
There are more than 50 hills within city limits.<sup id="cite_ref-peak_experience_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-peak_experience-51">[51]</a></sup> Some neighborhoods are named after the hill on which they are situated, including <a href="/wiki/Nob_Hill,_San_Francisco" title="Nob Hill, San Francisco">Nob Hill</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Potrero_Hill,_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Potrero Hill, San Francisco (page does not exist)">Potrero Hill</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Russian_Hill,_San_Francisco" title="Russian Hill, San Francisco">Russian Hill</a>.
Near the geographic center of the city, southwest of the downtown area, are a series of less densely populated hills. <a href="/wiki/Twin_Peaks_(San_Francisco)" title="Twin Peaks (San Francisco)">Twin Peaks</a>, a pair of hills forming one of the city's highest points, forms a popular overlook spot. San Francisco's tallest hill, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mount_Davidson_(California)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mount Davidson (California) (page does not exist)">Mount Davidson</a>, is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> high and is capped with a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> tall cross built in 1934.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup> Dominating this area is <a href="/wiki/Sutro_Tower" title="Sutro Tower">Sutro Tower</a>, a large red and white radio and television transmission tower.
</p><p>The nearby <a href="/wiki/San_Andreas_Fault" title="San Andreas Fault">San Andreas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hayward_Fault" title="Hayward Fault" class="mw-redirect">Hayward Faults</a> are responsible for much earthquake activity, although neither physically passes through the city itself. The San Andreas Fault caused the earthquakes in 1906 and 1989. Minor earthquakes occur on a regular basis. The threat of major earthquakes plays a large role in the city's infrastructure development. The city constructed an <a href="/w/index.php?title=San_Francisco_Fire_Department_Auxiliary_Water_Supply_System&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San Francisco Fire Department Auxiliary Water Supply System (page does not exist)">auxiliary water supply system</a> and has repeatedly upgraded its building codes, requiring retrofits for older buildings and higher engineering standards for new construction.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup> However, there are still thousands of smaller buildings that remain vulnerable to quake damage.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup>
</p><p>San Francisco's shoreline has grown beyond its natural limits. Entire neighborhoods such as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Marina_District,_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Marina District, San Francisco (page does not exist)">Marina</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mission_Bay,_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mission Bay, San Francisco (page does not exist)">Mission Bay</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hunters_Point,_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hunters Point, San Francisco (page does not exist)">Hunters Point</a>, as well as large sections of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Embarcadero_(San_Francisco)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Embarcadero (San Francisco) (page does not exist)">Embarcadero</a>, sit on areas of <a href="/wiki/Land_reclamation" title="Land reclamation">landfill</a>. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Treasure_Island,_California&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Treasure Island, California (page does not exist)">Treasure Island</a> was constructed from material dredged from the bay as well as material resulting from tunneling through Yerba Buena Island during the construction of the Bay Bridge. Such land tends to be unstable during earthquakes. The resulting <a href="/wiki/Earthquake_liquefaction" title="Earthquake liquefaction" class="mw-redirect">liquefaction</a> causes extensive damage to property built upon it, as was evidenced in the Marina district during the <a href="/wiki/1989_Loma_Prieta_earthquake" title="1989 Loma Prieta earthquake">1989 Loma Prieta earthquake</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup> Most of the city's natural watercourses, such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Islais_Creek&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Islais Creek (page does not exist)">Islais Creek</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mission_Creek&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mission Creek (page does not exist)">Mission Creek</a>, have been culverted and built over, although the <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Public_Utilities_Commission" title="San Francisco Public Utilities Commission">Public Utilities Commission</a> is studying proposals to daylight or restore some creeks.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Climate_chart&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Climate chart (page does not exist)">Template:Climate chart</a>
A popular quote incorrectly attributed to <a href="/wiki/Mark_Twain" title="Mark Twain">Mark Twain</a> is "The coldest winter I ever spent was a summer in San Francisco".<sup id="cite_ref-marktwain_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-marktwain-57">[57]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup> San Francisco's climate is characteristic of the cool-summer <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_climate" title="Mediterranean climate">Mediterranean climate</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Warm-summer_Mediterranean_climate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Warm-summer Mediterranean climate (page does not exist)">Csb</a>)<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup> of California’s coast, "generally characterized by moist mild winters and dry summers".<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup> Since it is surrounded on three sides by water, San Francisco's weather is strongly influenced by the <a href="/wiki/California_Current" title="California Current">cool currents</a> of the Pacific Ocean, which moderate temperature swings and produce a remarkably mild year-round climate with little seasonal temperature variation.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:San_francisco_in_fog_with_rays.jpg" title="File:San francisco in fog with rays.jpg">File:San francisco in fog with rays.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=San_Francisco_fog&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San Francisco fog (page does not exist)">Fog</a> is a regular feature of San Francisco summers.</div></div></div>
<p>Among major U.S. cities, San Francisco has the coldest daily mean, maximum, and minimum temperatures for June, July, and August.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup>
During the summer, rising hot air in California's interior valleys creates a low pressure area that draws winds from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=North_Pacific_High&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="North Pacific High (page does not exist)">North Pacific High</a> through the Golden Gate, which creates the city's <a href="/w/index.php?title=San_Francisco_fog_generation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San Francisco fog generation (page does not exist)">characteristic cool winds and fog</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup> The fog is less pronounced in eastern neighborhoods and during the late summer and early fall, which is the warmest time of the year.
</p><p>Because of its sharp topography and maritime influences, San Francisco exhibits a multitude of distinct <a href="/wiki/Microclimate" title="Microclimate">microclimates</a>. The high hills in the geographic center of the city are responsible for a 20% variance in annual rainfall between different parts of the city. They also protect neighborhoods directly to their east ("banana belts" such as Noe Valley) from the foggy and sometimes very cold and windy conditions experienced in the <a href="/wiki/Sunset_District,_San_Francisco" title="Sunset District, San Francisco">Sunset District</a>; for those who live on the eastern side of the city, San Francisco is sunnier, with an average of 260 clear days, and only 105 cloudy days per year.
</p><p>Temperatures exceed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> on average only 29&#160;days a year.<sup id="cite_ref-Weatherbase_63-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Weatherbase-63">[63]</a></sup> The dry period of May to October is mild to warm, with average high temperatures of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> and lows of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>. The rainy period of November to April is slightly cooler, with high temperatures of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> and lows of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>. On average, there are 73 rainy days a year, and annual precipitation averages <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>. Variation in precipitation from year to year is high. In 2013, a record low 5.8 inches of rainfall were recorded in San Francisco (low records were shattered in all of California). Snowfall in the city is very rare, with only 10 measurable accumulations recorded since 1852, most recently in 1976 when up to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> fell on Twin Peaks.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup>
</p><p>The highest recorded temperature at the official <a href="/wiki/National_Weather_Service" title="National Weather Service">National Weather Service</a> office was <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> on July 17, 1988, and June 14, 2000. The lowest recorded temperature was <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> on December 11, 1932.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup> The National Weather Service provides a helpful visual aid<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup> graphing the information in the table below to display visually by month the annual typical temperatures, the past year's temperatures, and record temperatures.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:San_Francisco_weatherbox&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:San Francisco weatherbox (page does not exist)">Template:San Francisco weatherbox</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Cityscape">Cityscape</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Wide_image&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Wide image (page does not exist)">Template:Wide image</a>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Wide_image&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Wide image (page does not exist)">Template:Wide image</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Neighborhoods">Neighborhoods</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:SF_Chinatown_CA.jpg" title="File:SF Chinatown CA.jpg">File:SF Chinatown CA.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">San Francisco's <a href="/wiki/Chinatown,_San_Francisco" title="Chinatown, San Francisco">Chinatown</a> is the oldest and one of the largest in North America.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The historic center of San Francisco is the northeast quadrant of the city anchored by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Market_Street_(San_Francisco)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Market Street (San Francisco) (page does not exist)">Market Street</a> and the waterfront. It is here that the <a href="/wiki/Financial_District,_San_Francisco" title="Financial District, San Francisco">Financial District</a> is centered, with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Union_Square_(San_Francisco)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Union Square (San Francisco) (page does not exist)">Union Square</a>, the principal shopping and hotel district, nearby. <a href="/wiki/Cable_car_(railway)" title="Cable car (railway)">Cable cars</a> carry riders up steep inclines to the summit of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nob_Hill&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nob Hill (page does not exist)">Nob Hill</a>, once the home of the city's business tycoons, and down to the waterfront tourist attractions of <a href="/wiki/Fisherman%27s_Wharf,_San_Francisco" title="Fisherman's Wharf, San Francisco">Fisherman's Wharf</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Pier_39" title="Pier 39">Pier 39</a>, where many restaurants feature <a href="/wiki/Dungeness_crab" title="Dungeness crab">Dungeness crab</a> from a still-active fishing industry. Also in this quadrant are <a href="/wiki/Russian_Hill,_San_Francisco" title="Russian Hill, San Francisco">Russian Hill</a>, a residential neighborhood with the famously crooked <a href="/wiki/Lombard_Street_(San_Francisco)" title="Lombard Street (San Francisco)">Lombard Street</a>; <a href="/wiki/North_Beach,_San_Francisco" title="North Beach, San Francisco">North Beach</a>, the city's <a href="/wiki/Little_Italy" title="Little Italy">Little Italy</a> and the former center of the <a href="/wiki/Beat_Generation" title="Beat Generation">Beat Generation</a>; and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Telegraph_Hill,_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Telegraph Hill, San Francisco (page does not exist)">Telegraph Hill</a>, which features <a href="/wiki/Coit_Tower" title="Coit Tower">Coit Tower</a>. Between Russian Hill and North Beach is San Francisco's <a href="/wiki/Chinatown,_San_Francisco" title="Chinatown, San Francisco">Chinatown</a>, the oldest <a href="/wiki/Chinatown" title="Chinatown">Chinatown</a> in North America.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Bacon.2C_Daniel_pages_52-53_70-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bacon.2C_Daniel_pages_52-53-70">[70]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/South_of_Market,_San_Francisco" title="South of Market, San Francisco">South of Market</a>, which was once San Francisco's industrial core, has seen significant redevelopment following the addition of <a href="/wiki/AT%26T_Park" title="AT&amp;T Park">AT&amp;T Park</a> and an infusion of <a href="/wiki/Startup_company" title="Startup company">startup companies</a>. New skyscrapers, live-work lofts, and condominiums dot the area. Further development is taking place just to the south in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mission_Bay,_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mission Bay, San Francisco (page does not exist)">Mission Bay</a>, a former railyard now anchored by a second campus of the <a href="/wiki/University_of_California,_San_Francisco" title="University of California, San Francisco">University of California, San Francisco</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:DowntownSF.jpg" title="File:DowntownSF.jpg">File:DowntownSF.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Financial_District,_San_Francisco" title="Financial District, San Francisco">Financial District</a> from the Bay Bridge</div></div></div>
<p>West of downtown, across <a href="/w/index.php?title=Van_Ness_Avenue_(San_Francisco)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Van Ness Avenue (San Francisco) (page does not exist)">Van Ness Avenue</a>, lies the large <a href="/wiki/Western_Addition,_San_Francisco" title="Western Addition, San Francisco">Western Addition</a> neighborhood, which became established with a large African American population after <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>. The Western Addition is usually divided into smaller neighborhoods including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hayes_Valley,_San_Francisco,_California&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hayes Valley, San Francisco, California (page does not exist)">Hayes Valley</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fillmore_District,_San_Francisco,_California&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fillmore District, San Francisco, California (page does not exist)">the Fillmore</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Japantown,_San_Francisco" title="Japantown, San Francisco">Japantown</a>, which was once the largest Japantown in North America but suffered when its <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese American (page does not exist)">Japanese American</a> residents were <a href="/wiki/Japanese_American_internment" title="Japanese American internment">forcibly removed and interned</a> during World War II. The Western Addition survived the <a href="/w/index.php?title=1906_San_Francisco_earthquake&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="1906 San Francisco earthquake (page does not exist)">1906 earthquake</a> with its <a href="/w/index.php?title=Victorian_house&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Victorian house (page does not exist)">Victorians</a> largely intact, including the famous "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Painted_Ladies&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Painted Ladies (page does not exist)">Painted Ladies</a>", standing alongside <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alamo_Square&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alamo Square (page does not exist)">Alamo Square</a>. To the south, near the geographic center of the city is <a href="/wiki/Haight-Ashbury" title="Haight-Ashbury">Haight-Ashbury</a>, famously associated with 1960s <a href="/wiki/Hippie" title="Hippie">hippie</a> culture. The Haight is now home to some expensive boutiques<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup> and a few controversial chain stores,<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup> although it still retains some <a href="/wiki/Bohemianism" title="Bohemianism">bohemian</a> character. North of the Western Addition is <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Heights,_San_Francisco" title="Pacific Heights, San Francisco">Pacific Heights</a>, a wealthy neighborhood that features the mansions built by the San Francisco business elite in the wake of the 1906 earthquake. Directly north of Pacific Heights facing the waterfront is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Marina_District,_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Marina District, San Francisco (page does not exist)">Marina</a>, a neighborhood popular with young professionals that was largely built on reclaimed land from the Bay.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:SF_Transamerica_full_CA.jpg" title="File:SF Transamerica full CA.jpg">File:SF Transamerica full CA.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Transamerica_Pyramid" title="Transamerica Pyramid">Transamerica Pyramid</a> is the tallest building in San Francisco</div></div></div>
<p>In the south-east quadrant of the city is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mission_District&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mission District (page does not exist)">Mission District</a>—populated in the 19th century by <a href="/wiki/Californio" title="Californio">Californios</a> and working-class immigrants from Germany, Ireland, Italy, and Scandinavia. In the 1910s, a wave of Central American immigrants settled in the Mission and, in the 1950s, immigrants from <a href="/wiki/Mexican_American" title="Mexican American">Mexico</a> began to predominate.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup> In recent years, gentrification has changed the demographics of parts of the Mission from Latino, to <a href="/wiki/Twentysomething_(term)" title="Twentysomething (term)" class="mw-redirect">twenty-something</a> professionals. <a href="/wiki/Noe_Valley,_San_Francisco" title="Noe Valley, San Francisco">Noe Valley</a> to the southwest and <a href="/wiki/Bernal_Heights,_San_Francisco" title="Bernal Heights, San Francisco">Bernal Heights</a> to the south are both increasingly popular among young families with children. East of the Mission is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Potrero_Hill&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Potrero Hill (page does not exist)">Potrero Hill</a> neighborhood, a mostly residential neighborhood that features sweeping views of downtown San Francisco. West of the Mission, the area historically known as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eureka_Valley_(San_Francisco)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eureka Valley (San Francisco) (page does not exist)">Eureka Valley</a>, now popularly called <a href="/wiki/The_Castro,_San_Francisco" title="The Castro, San Francisco">the Castro</a>, was once a working-class Scandinavian and Irish area. It has become North America's first and best known <a href="/wiki/Gay_village" title="Gay village">gay village</a>, and is now the center of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Homosexuality&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Homosexuality (page does not exist)">gay</a> life in the city.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup> Located near the city's southern border, the <a href="/wiki/Excelsior_District,_San_Francisco" title="Excelsior District, San Francisco">Excelsior District</a> is one of the most ethnically diverse neighborhoods in San Francisco. The predominately African American <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hunters_Point,_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hunters Point, San Francisco (page does not exist)">Bayview-Hunters Point</a> in the far southeast corner of the city is one of the poorest neighborhoods and suffers from a high rate of crime, though the area has been the focus of several revitalizing and controversial <a href="/wiki/Urban_renewal" title="Urban renewal">urban renewal</a> projects.
</p><p>The construction of the <a href="/wiki/Twin_Peaks_Tunnel" title="Twin Peaks Tunnel">Twin Peaks Tunnel</a> in 1918 connected southwest neighborhoods to downtown via streetcar, hastening the development of <a href="/wiki/West_Portal,_San_Francisco" title="West Portal, San Francisco">West Portal</a>, and nearby affluent <a href="/wiki/Forest_Hill,_San_Francisco" title="Forest Hill, San Francisco">Forest Hill</a> and <a href="/wiki/St._Francis_Wood,_San_Francisco" title="St. Francis Wood, San Francisco">St. Francis Wood</a>. Further west, stretching all the way to the Pacific Ocean and north to <a href="/wiki/Golden_Gate_Park" title="Golden Gate Park">Golden Gate Park</a> lies the vast <a href="/wiki/Sunset_District,_San_Francisco" title="Sunset District, San Francisco">Sunset District</a>, a large middle class area with a predominantly Asian population.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup>
The northwestern quadrant of the city contains the <a href="/wiki/Richmond_District,_San_Francisco" title="Richmond District, San Francisco">Richmond</a>, also a mostly middle-class neighborhood north of Golden Gate Park, home to immigrants from other parts of Asia as well as many <a href="/wiki/Russian_people" title="Russian people" class="mw-redirect">Russian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_people" title="Ukrainian people" class="mw-redirect">Ukrainian</a> immigrants. Together, these areas are known as <a href="/wiki/Neighborhoods_in_San_Francisco" title="Neighborhoods in San Francisco">The Avenues</a>. These two districts are each sometimes further divided into two regions: the Outer Richmond and Outer Sunset can refer to the more western portions of their respective district and the Inner Richmond and Inner Sunset can refer to the more eastern portions.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Beaches_and_parks">Beaches and parks</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:SF_Conservatory_of_Flowers_3.jpg" title="File:SF Conservatory of Flowers 3.jpg">File:SF Conservatory of Flowers 3.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Conservatory_of_Flowers" title="Conservatory of Flowers">Conservatory of Flowers</a> in <a href="/wiki/Golden_Gate_Park" title="Golden Gate Park">Golden Gate Park</a></div></div></div>
<p>Several of San Francisco's parks and nearly all of its beaches form part of the regional <a href="/w/index.php?title=Golden_Gate_National_Recreation_Area&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Golden Gate National Recreation Area (page does not exist)">Golden Gate National Recreation Area</a>, one of the most visited units of the <a href="/wiki/National_Park_Service" title="National Park Service">National Park system</a> in the United States with over 13&#160;million visitors a year. Among the GGNRA's attractions within the city are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ocean_Beach_(San_Francisco)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ocean Beach (San Francisco) (page does not exist)">Ocean Beach</a>, which runs along the Pacific Ocean shoreline and is frequented by a vibrant <a href="/wiki/Surfing" title="Surfing">surfing</a> community, and <a href="/wiki/Baker_Beach" title="Baker Beach">Baker Beach</a>, which is located in a cove west of the Golden Gate and part of the <a href="/wiki/Presidio_of_San_Francisco" title="Presidio of San Francisco">Presidio</a>, a former military base. Also within the Presidio is <a href="/wiki/Crissy_Field" title="Crissy Field">Crissy Field</a>, a former airfield that was restored to its natural <a href="/wiki/Salt_marsh" title="Salt marsh">salt marsh</a> <a href="/wiki/Ecosystem" title="Ecosystem">ecosystem</a>. The GGNRA also administers <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fort_Funston&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fort Funston (page does not exist)">Fort Funston</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lands_End,_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lands End, San Francisco (page does not exist)">Lands End</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fort_Mason&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fort Mason (page does not exist)">Fort Mason</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alcatraz&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alcatraz (page does not exist)">Alcatraz</a>. The National Park Service separately administers the <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Maritime_National_Historical_Park" title="San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park">San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park</a> – a fleet of historic ships and waterfront property around <a href="/w/index.php?title=Aquatic_Park_Historic_District&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aquatic Park Historic District (page does not exist)">Aquatic Park</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Alamo_Square_with_Painted_Ladies,_SF,_CA,_jjron_26.03.2012.jpg" title="File:Alamo Square with Painted Ladies, SF, CA, jjron 26.03.2012.jpg">File:Alamo Square with Painted Ladies, SF, CA, jjron 26.03.2012.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Alamo_Square&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alamo Square (page does not exist)">Alamo Square</a> is one of the most well known parks in the area, and is often a symbol of San Francisco for its popular location for film and pop culture.</div></div></div>
<p>There are more than <a href="/wiki/List_of_parks_in_San_Francisco" title="List of parks in San Francisco">220 parks</a> maintained by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=San_Francisco_Recreation_%26_Parks_Department&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San Francisco Recreation &amp; Parks Department (page does not exist)">San Francisco Recreation &amp; Parks Department</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup> The largest and best-known city park is <a href="/wiki/Golden_Gate_Park" title="Golden Gate Park">Golden Gate Park</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup> which stretches from the center of the city west to the Pacific Ocean. Once covered in native grasses and sand dunes, the park was conceived in the 1860s and was created by the extensive planting of thousands of non-native trees and plants. The large park is rich with cultural and natural attractions such as the <a href="/wiki/Conservatory_of_Flowers" title="Conservatory of Flowers">Conservatory of Flowers</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_tea_garden_at_Golden_Gate_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese tea garden at Golden Gate Park (page does not exist)">Japanese Tea Garden</a> and <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Botanical_Garden" title="San Francisco Botanical Garden">San Francisco Botanical Garden</a>. <a href="/wiki/Lake_Merced" title="Lake Merced">Lake Merced</a> is a fresh-water lake surrounded by parkland and near the <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Zoo" title="San Francisco Zoo">San Francisco Zoo</a>, a city-owned park that houses more than 250 animal species, many of which are endangered.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup> The only <a href="/wiki/List_of_California_state_parks" title="List of California state parks">park</a> managed by the <a href="/wiki/California_Department_of_Parks_and_Recreation" title="California Department of Parks and Recreation">California State Park</a> system located principally in San Francisco, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Candlestick_Point_State_Recreation_Area&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Candlestick Point State Recreation Area (page does not exist)">Candlestick Point</a> was the state's first urban recreation area.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture_and_contemporary_life">Culture and contemporary life</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Fillmore-sidewalk-1.jpg" title="File:Fillmore-sidewalk-1.jpg">File:Fillmore-sidewalk-1.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Boutiques along <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fillmore_Street&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fillmore Street (page does not exist)">Fillmore Street</a> in <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Heights,_San_Francisco" title="Pacific Heights, San Francisco">Pacific Heights</a></div></div></div>
<p>Although the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Financial_District_(San_Francisco)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Financial District (San Francisco) (page does not exist)">Financial District</a>, <a href="/wiki/Union_Square,_San_Francisco" title="Union Square, San Francisco">Union Square</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Fisherman%27s_Wharf,_San_Francisco" title="Fisherman's Wharf, San Francisco">Fisherman's Wharf</a> are well-known around the world, San Francisco is also characterized by its numerous culturally rich streetscapes featuring <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mixed-use_development&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mixed-use development (page does not exist)">mixed-use</a> neighborhoods anchored around <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_streets_in_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of streets in San Francisco (page does not exist)">central commercial corridors</a> to which residents and visitors alike can walk. Because of these characteristics, San Francisco was rated "most walkable" city by the website Walkscore.com.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup> Many neighborhoods feature a mix of businesses, restaurants and venues that cater to both the daily needs of local residents while also serving many visitors and tourists. Some neighborhoods are dotted with boutiques, cafes and nightlife such as Union Street in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cow_Hollow,_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cow Hollow, San Francisco (page does not exist)">Cow Hollow</a>, 24th Street in <a href="/wiki/Noe_Valley,_San_Francisco" title="Noe Valley, San Francisco">Noe Valley</a>, Valencia Street in the <a href="/wiki/Mission_District,_San_Francisco" title="Mission District, San Francisco">Mission</a>, and Irving Street in the <a href="/wiki/Sunset_District,_San_Francisco" title="Sunset District, San Francisco">Inner Sunset</a>. This approach especially has influenced the continuing South of Market neighborhood redevelopment with businesses and neighborhood services rising alongside high-rise residences.<sup id="cite_ref-FogDev_84-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FogDev-84">[84]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:South_of_Market,_San_Francisco.jpg" title="File:South of Market, San Francisco.jpg">File:South of Market, San Francisco.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">High-rises surround <a href="/wiki/Yerba_Buena_Gardens" title="Yerba Buena Gardens">Yerba Buena Gardens</a>, South of Market</div></div></div>
<p>Since the 1990s, the demand for skilled <a href="/w/index.php?title=Information_technology&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Information technology (page does not exist)">information technology</a> workers from local startups and nearby <a href="/wiki/Silicon_Valley" title="Silicon Valley">Silicon Valley</a> has attracted <a href="/wiki/White-collar_worker" title="White-collar worker">white-collar workers</a> from all over the world and created a high standard of living in San Francisco.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup> Many neighborhoods that were once <a href="/wiki/Blue-collar" title="Blue-collar" class="mw-redirect">blue-collar</a>, middle, and lower class have been <a href="/wiki/Gentrification" title="Gentrification">gentrifying</a>, as many of the city's traditional business and industrial districts have experienced a renaissance driven by the redevelopment of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Embarcadero_(San_Francisco)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Embarcadero (San Francisco) (page does not exist)">Embarcadero</a>, including the neighborhoods <a href="/w/index.php?title=South_Beach,_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="South Beach, San Francisco (page does not exist)">South Beach</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mission_Bay,_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mission Bay, San Francisco (page does not exist)">Mission Bay</a>.
