The city's property values and household income have risen to among the highest in the nation,<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-MedianIncome_87-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MedianIncome-87">[87]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup> creating a large and upscale restaurant, retail, and entertainment scene. According to a 2008 quality of life survey of global cities, San Francisco has the second <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_cities_by_quality_of_living&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of cities by quality of living (page does not exist)">highest quality of living</a> of any U.S. city.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup> However, due to the exceptionally high cost of living, many of the city's middle and lower-class families have been leaving the city for the outer suburbs of the Bay Area, or for California's <a href="/wiki/Central_Valley_(California)" title="Central Valley (California)">Central Valley</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-MiddleClass_90-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MiddleClass-90">[90]</a></sup>
</p><p>The international character that San Francisco has enjoyed since its founding is continued today by large numbers of immigrants from Asia and Latin America. With 39% of its residents born overseas,<sup id="cite_ref-SFEconomicStrategy_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SFEconomicStrategy-91">[91]</a></sup> San Francisco has numerous neighborhoods filled with businesses and civic institutions catering to new arrivals. In particular, the arrival of many ethnic Chinese, which accelerated beginning in the 1970s, has complemented the long-established community historically based in <a href="/wiki/Chinatown,_San_Francisco" title="Chinatown, San Francisco">Chinatown</a> throughout the city and has transformed the annual <a href="/w/index.php?title=San_Francisco_Chinese_New_Year_Festival_and_Parade&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San Francisco Chinese New Year Festival and Parade (page does not exist)">Chinese New Year Parade</a> into the largest event of its kind outside China.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Castro_Rainbow_Flag.jpg" title="File:Castro Rainbow Flag.jpg">File:Castro Rainbow Flag.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rainbow_flag_(LGBT_movement)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rainbow flag (LGBT movement) (page does not exist)">rainbow flag</a>, symbol of <a href="/wiki/LGBT" title="LGBT">LGBT</a> pride, originated in San Francisco; banners like this one decorate streets in <a href="/wiki/The_Castro,_San_Francisco" title="The Castro, San Francisco">The Castro</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>With the arrival of the <a href="/wiki/Beat_Generation" title="Beat Generation">"beat"</a> writers and artists of the 1950s and societal changes culminating in the <a href="/wiki/Summer_of_Love" title="Summer of Love">Summer of Love</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Haight-Ashbury" title="Haight-Ashbury">Haight-Ashbury</a> district during the 1960s, San Francisco became a center of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Modern_liberalism_in_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Modern liberalism in the United States (page does not exist)">liberal</a> activism. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Democratic_Party_(United_States)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Democratic Party (United States) (page does not exist)">Democrats</a> and to a lesser extent the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Green_Party_(United_States)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Green Party (United States) (page does not exist)">Green Party</a> have dominated <a href="/w/index.php?title=Politics_of_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Politics of San Francisco (page does not exist)">city politics</a> since the late 1970s, after the <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_Barbagelata&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John Barbagelata (page does not exist)">last serious</a> <a href="/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)" title="Republican Party (United States)">Republican</a> challenger for city office <a href="/w/index.php?title=San_Francisco_mayoral_election,_1975&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San Francisco mayoral election, 1975 (page does not exist)">lost the 1975 mayoral election</a> by a narrow margin. San Francisco has not voted more than 20% for a <a href="/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)" title="Republican Party (United States)">Republican</a> presidential or senatorial candidate since <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1988" title="United States presidential election, 1988">1988</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup> In 2007, the city expanded its <a href="/wiki/Medicaid" title="Medicaid">Medicaid</a> and other <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indigent&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indigent (page does not exist)">indigent</a> medical programs into the "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Healthy_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Healthy San Francisco (page does not exist)">Healthy San Francisco</a>" program,<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup> which <a href="/wiki/Subsidy" title="Subsidy">subsidizes</a> certain medical services for eligible residents.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup>
</p><p>San Francisco has long had an <a href="/wiki/LGBT" title="LGBT">LGBT</a>-friendly history. It was home to the first lesbian-rights organization in the United States, <a href="/wiki/Daughters_of_Bilitis" title="Daughters of Bilitis">Daughters of Bilitis</a>; the first openly gay person to run for public office in the U.S., <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Sarria" title="José Sarria">José Sarria</a>; the first openly gay man to be elected to public office in the U.S., <a href="/wiki/Harvey_Milk" title="Harvey Milk">Harvey Milk</a>; the first openly lesbian judge appointed in the U.S., <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mary_C._Morgan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mary C. Morgan (page does not exist)">Mary C. Morgan</a>; and the first <a href="/w/index.php?title=Transgender&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Transgender (page does not exist)">transgender</a> police commissioner, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Theresa_Sparks&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Theresa Sparks (page does not exist)">Theresa Sparks</a>. The city's large gay population has created and sustained a politically and culturally active community over many decades, developing a powerful presence in San Francisco's civic life. One of the most popular destinations for gay tourists internationally, the city hosts <a href="/w/index.php?title=San_Francisco_Pride&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San Francisco Pride (page does not exist)">San Francisco Pride</a>, one of the largest and oldest <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pride_parades&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pride parades (page does not exist)">pride parades</a>.
</p><p>San Francisco also has had a very active environmental community. Starting with the founding of the <a href="/wiki/Sierra_Club" title="Sierra Club">Sierra Club</a> in 1892 to the establishment of the non-profit <a href="/w/index.php?title=Friends_of_the_Urban_Forest&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Friends of the Urban Forest (page does not exist)">Friends of the Urban Forest</a> in 1981, San Francisco has been at the forefront of many globally discussions regarding our natural environment.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup> The 1980 <a href="/w/index.php?title=San_Francisco_Mandatory_Recycling_and_Composting_Ordinance&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San Francisco Mandatory Recycling and Composting Ordinance (page does not exist)">San Francisco Recycling Program</a> was one of the earliest curbside recycling programs.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup> The city's GoSolarSF incentive promotes solar installations and the <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Public_Utilities_Commission" title="San Francisco Public Utilities Commission">San Francisco Public Utilities Commission</a> is rolling out the <a href="/w/index.php?title=CleanPowerSF&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="CleanPowerSF (page does not exist)">CleanPowerSF</a> program to sell electricity from local renewable sources.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup> SF Greasecycle is a program to recycle used cooking oil for conversion to biodiesel.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup>
</p><p>The newly completed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sunset_Reservoir&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sunset Reservoir (page does not exist)">Sunset Reservoir</a> Solar Project has installed 25,000 solar panels on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> roof of the reservoir. The 5-megawatt plant more than tripled the city's 2-megawatt solar generation capacity when it opened in December 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[105]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Entertainment_and_performing_arts">Entertainment and performing arts</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:SFWMOHLobbySouth.jpg" title="File:SFWMOHLobbySouth.jpg">File:SFWMOHLobbySouth.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The lobby of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=War_Memorial_Opera_House_(San_Francisco)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="War Memorial Opera House (San Francisco) (page does not exist)">War Memorial Opera House</a>, one of the last buildings erected in <a href="/wiki/Beaux-Arts_architecture" title="Beaux-Arts architecture">Beaux Arts</a> style in the United States</div></div></div>
<p>San Francisco's <a href="/w/index.php?title=San_Francisco_War_Memorial_and_Performing_Arts_Center&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San Francisco War Memorial and Performing Arts Center (page does not exist)">War Memorial and Performing Arts Center</a> hosts some of the most enduring performing-arts companies in the U.S. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=War_Memorial_Opera_House&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="War Memorial Opera House (page does not exist)">War Memorial Opera House</a> houses the <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Opera" title="San Francisco Opera">San Francisco Opera</a>, the second-largest opera company in North America<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup> as well as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=San_Francisco_Ballet&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San Francisco Ballet (page does not exist)">San Francisco Ballet</a>, while the <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Symphony" title="San Francisco Symphony">San Francisco Symphony</a> plays in <a href="/wiki/Louise_M._Davies_Symphony_Hall" title="Louise M. Davies Symphony Hall">Davies Symphony Hall</a>. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Herbst_Theatre&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Herbst Theatre (page does not exist)">Herbst Theatre</a> stages an eclectic mix of music performances, as well as <a href="/w/index.php?title=National_Public_Radio&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National Public Radio (page does not exist)">public radio</a>'s <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=City_Arts_%26_Lectures&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="City Arts &amp; Lectures (page does not exist)">City Arts &amp; Lectures</a>.</i>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/The_Fillmore" title="The Fillmore">The Fillmore</a> is a music venue located in the <a href="/wiki/Western_Addition,_San_Francisco" title="Western Addition, San Francisco">Western Addition</a>. It is the second incarnation of the historic venue that gained fame in the 1960s under concert promoter <a href="/wiki/Bill_Graham_(promoter)" title="Bill Graham (promoter)">Bill Graham</a>, housing the stage where now-famous musicians such as the <a href="/wiki/Grateful_Dead" title="Grateful Dead">Grateful Dead</a>, <a href="/wiki/Janis_Joplin" title="Janis Joplin">Janis Joplin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Led_Zeppelin" title="Led Zeppelin">Led Zeppelin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jefferson_Airplane" title="Jefferson Airplane">Jefferson Airplane</a> first performed, fostering the <a href="/w/index.php?title=San_Francisco_Sound&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San Francisco Sound (page does not exist)">San Francisco Sound</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Beach_Blanket_Babylon" title="Beach Blanket Babylon">Beach Blanket Babylon</a></i> is a zany musical revue and a civic institution that has performed to sold-out crowds in <a href="/wiki/North_Beach,_San_Francisco" title="North Beach, San Francisco">North Beach</a> since 1974.
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=American_Conservatory_Theater&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="American Conservatory Theater (page does not exist)">American Conservatory Theater</a> (A.C.T.) has been a force in Bay Area performing arts since its arrival in San Francisco in 1967, regularly staging productions. San Francisco frequently hosts national touring productions of Broadway theatre shows in a number of vintage 1920s-era venues in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Theater_District,_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Theater District, San Francisco (page does not exist)">Theater District</a> including the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_theatres_in_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of theatres in San Francisco (page does not exist)">Curran</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_theatres_in_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of theatres in San Francisco (page does not exist)">Orpheum</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_theatres_in_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of theatres in San Francisco (page does not exist)">Golden Gate</a> Theatres.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:San_Francisco_Museum_of_Modern_Art_in_2011.jpg" title="File:San Francisco Museum of Modern Art in 2011.jpg">File:San Francisco Museum of Modern Art in 2011.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The red brick and central circular structure of the <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Museum_of_Modern_Art" title="San Francisco Museum of Modern Art">San Francisco Museum of Modern Art</a> as seen from <a href="/wiki/Yerba_Buena_Gardens" title="Yerba Buena Gardens">Yerba Buena Gardens</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Art_Deco" title="Art Deco">Art Deco</a>-style <a href="/w/index.php?title=140_New_Montgomery&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="140 New Montgomery (page does not exist)">Pacific Telephone Building</a> (1925) rises behind the museum.</div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Museums">Museums</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Museum_of_Modern_Art" title="San Francisco Museum of Modern Art">San Francisco Museum of Modern Art</a> (SFMOMA) houses 20th century and contemporary works of art. It moved to its current building in the <a href="/wiki/South_of_Market,_San_Francisco" title="South of Market, San Francisco">South of Market</a> neighborhood in 1995 and now attracts more than 600,000 visitors annually.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=California_Palace_of_the_Legion_of_Honor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="California Palace of the Legion of Honor (page does not exist)">Palace of the Legion of Honor</a> holds primarily European antiquities and works of art at its <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lincoln_Park_(San_Francisco)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lincoln Park (San Francisco) (page does not exist)">Lincoln Park</a> building modeled after its <a href="/w/index.php?title=Palais_de_la_L%C3%A9gion_d%27Honneur&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Palais de la Légion d'Honneur (page does not exist)">Parisian namesake</a>. It is administered by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fine_Arts_Museums_of_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco (page does not exist)">Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco</a>, which also operates the <a href="/w/index.php?title=M._H._de_Young_Memorial_Museum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="M. H. de Young Memorial Museum (page does not exist)">de Young Museum</a> in Golden Gate Park. The de Young's collection features American decorative pieces and anthropological holdings from Africa, Oceania and the Americas. Prior to construction of its current copper-clad structure, completed in 2005, the de Young also housed the <a href="/wiki/Asian_Art_Museum_of_San_Francisco" title="Asian Art Museum of San Francisco">Asian Art Museum</a>, which, with artifacts from over 6,000&#160;years of history across Asia, moved into the former <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Public_Library" title="San Francisco Public Library">public library</a> next to <a href="/wiki/Civic_Center,_San_Francisco" title="Civic Center, San Francisco">Civic Center</a> in 2003.
</p><p>Opposite the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Music_Concourse&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Music Concourse (page does not exist)">Music Concourse</a> from the de Young stands the <a href="/wiki/California_Academy_of_Sciences" title="California Academy of Sciences">California Academy of Sciences</a>, a natural history museum that also hosts the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Morrison_Planetarium&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Morrison Planetarium (page does not exist)">Morrison Planetarium</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Steinhart_Aquarium&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Steinhart Aquarium (page does not exist)">Steinhart Aquarium</a>. Its current structure, featuring a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Living_roof&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Living roof (page does not exist)">living roof</a>, is an example of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sustainable_architecture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sustainable architecture (page does not exist)">sustainable architecture</a> and opened in 2008. Located on Pier 15 on the Embarcadero, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Exploratorium&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Exploratorium (page does not exist)">Exploratorium</a> is an interactive science museum founded by physicist <a href="/wiki/Frank_Oppenheimer" title="Frank Oppenheimer">Frank Oppenheimer</a> in 1969. Two museum ships are moored near Fisherman's Wharf, the <a href="/wiki/SS_Jeremiah_O%27Brien" title="SS Jeremiah O'Brien">SS <i>Jeremiah O'Brien</i></a> Liberty ship and <a href="/wiki/USS_Pampanito_(SS-383)" title="USS Pampanito (SS-383)">USS <i>Pampanito</i></a> submarine. On Nob Hill, the <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Cable_Car_Museum" title="San Francisco Cable Car Museum">Cable Car Museum</a> is a working museum featuring the cable car power house, which drives the cables, and the car depot.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The major daily newspaper in San Francisco is the <i><a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Chronicle" title="San Francisco Chronicle">San Francisco Chronicle</a></i>, which is currently Northern California's most widely circulated newspaper.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup> The Chronicle is most famous for a former columnist, the late <a href="/wiki/Herb_Caen" title="Herb Caen">Herb Caen</a>, whose daily musings attracted critical acclaim and represented the "voice of San Francisco". The <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=San_Francisco_Examiner&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San Francisco Examiner (page does not exist)">San Francisco Examiner</a></i>, once the cornerstone of <a href="/wiki/William_Randolph_Hearst" title="William Randolph Hearst">William Randolph Hearst</a>'s media empire and the home of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ambrose_Bierce&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ambrose Bierce (page does not exist)">Ambrose Bierce</a>, declined in circulation over the years and now takes the form of a free daily tabloid, under new ownership.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Sing_Tao_Daily" title="Sing Tao Daily">Sing Tao Daily</a></i> claims to be the largest of several Chinese language dailies that serve the Bay Area.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alternative_weekly&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alternative weekly (page does not exist)">Alternative weekly</a> newspapers include the <i><a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Bay_Guardian" title="San Francisco Bay Guardian">San Francisco Bay Guardian</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/SF_Weekly" title="SF Weekly">SF&#160;Weekly</a></i>. <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=San_Francisco_Magazine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San Francisco Magazine (page does not exist)">San Francisco Magazine</a></i> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=7x7_(magazine)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="7x7 (magazine) (page does not exist)">7x7</a></i> are major glossy magazines about San Francisco. The national newsmagazine <i><a href="/wiki/Mother_Jones_(magazine)" title="Mother Jones (magazine)">Mother Jones</a></i> is also based in San Francisco.
</p><p>The San Francisco Bay Area is the sixth-largest <a href="/wiki/Designated_market_area" title="Designated market area" class="mw-redirect">TV&#160;market</a><sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup> and the fourth-largest <a href="/wiki/Designated_market_area" title="Designated market area" class="mw-redirect">radio market</a><sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup> in the U.S. The city's oldest radio station, <a href="/wiki/KCBS_(AM)" title="KCBS (AM)">KCBS (AM)</a>, began as an experimental station in San Jose in 1909, before the beginning of commercial broadcasting. <a href="/wiki/KALW" title="KALW">KALW</a> was the city's first FM radio station when it signed on the air in 1941. All major U.S. television networks have <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_television_stations_in_the_San_Francisco_Bay_Area&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of television stations in the San Francisco Bay Area (page does not exist)">affiliates</a> serving the region, with most of them based in the city. There also are several unaffiliated stations. <a href="/wiki/CNN" title="CNN">CNN</a>, <a href="/wiki/ESPN" title="ESPN">ESPN</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=BBC&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BBC (page does not exist)">BBC</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Al_Jazeera_America&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Al Jazeera America (page does not exist)">Al Jazeera America</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=RT_(TV_network)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="RT (TV network) (page does not exist)">Russia Today</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=CCTV_America&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="CCTV America (page does not exist)">CCTV America</a> have regional news bureaus in San Francisco. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bloomberg_West&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bloomberg West (page does not exist)">Bloomberg West</a> was launched in 2011 from a studio on the Embarcadero. The city's first television station was <a href="/wiki/KPIX" title="KPIX" class="mw-redirect">KPIX</a>, which began broadcasting in 1948.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Public_broadcasting" title="Public broadcasting">Public broadcasting</a> outlets include both a <a href="/w/index.php?title=KQED-TV&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="KQED-TV (page does not exist)">television station</a> and a <a href="/wiki/KQED-FM" title="KQED-FM">radio station</a>, both broadcasting under the call letters KQED from a facility near the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Potrero_Hill,_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Potrero Hill, San Francisco (page does not exist)">Potrero Hill</a> neighborhood. KQED-FM is the most-listened-to <a href="/w/index.php?title=National_Public_Radio&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National Public Radio (page does not exist)">National Public Radio</a> affiliate in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup> San Francisco–based <a href="/wiki/CNET_Networks" title="CNET Networks" class="mw-redirect">CNET</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Salon.com&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Salon.com (page does not exist)">Salon.com</a> pioneered the use of the Internet as a media outlet. Satellite channel non-commercial <a href="/wiki/Link_TV" title="Link TV">Link TV</a> was launched in 1999 from San Francisco.
</p><p>San Francisco inventors have made significant marks on modern media. In 1877 <a href="/wiki/Eadweard_Muybridge" title="Eadweard Muybridge">Eadweard Muybridge</a> pioneered work in photographic studies of motion and in motion-picture projection from. These were the first motion pictures. Then in 1927, <a href="/wiki/Philo_Farnsworth" title="Philo Farnsworth">Philo Farnsworth's</a> image dissector camera tube transmitted its first image. This was the first television.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports_and_recreation">Sports and recreation</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Major_League_Baseball" title="Major League Baseball">Major League Baseball</a>'s <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Giants" title="San Francisco Giants">San Francisco Giants</a> left New York for California prior to the 1958 season and are currently the only major professional sports franchise in the city. Though boasting such stars as <a href="/wiki/Willie_Mays" title="Willie Mays">Willie Mays</a>, <a href="/wiki/Willie_McCovey" title="Willie McCovey">Willie McCovey</a> and <a href="/wiki/Barry_Bonds" title="Barry Bonds">Barry Bonds</a>, the club went 52 years until its first <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_Series&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World Series (page does not exist)">World Series</a> title in <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_World_Series&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 World Series (page does not exist)">2010</a>, and won an additional title in <a href="/w/index.php?title=2012_World_Series&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2012 World Series (page does not exist)">2012</a>. The Giants play at <a href="/wiki/AT%26T_Park" title="AT&amp;T Park">AT&amp;T Park</a>, which opened in 2000, a cornerstone project of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=South_Beach,_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="South Beach, San Francisco (page does not exist)">South Beach</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mission_Bay,_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mission Bay, San Francisco (page does not exist)">Mission Bay</a> redevelopment.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup> In 2012, San Francisco was ranked #1 among America's Best Baseball cities. The study examined which U.S. metro areas have produced the most Major Leaguers since 1920.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:AT%26T_Park.jpg" title="File:AT&amp;T Park.jpg">File:AT&amp;T Park.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/AT%26T_Park" title="AT&amp;T Park">AT&amp;T Park</a> opened in 2000.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_49ers" title="San Francisco 49ers">San Francisco 49ers</a> of the <a href="/wiki/National_Football_League" title="National Football League">National Football League</a> (NFL) were the longest-tenured major professional sports franchise in the city. The team began play in 1946 as an <a href="/wiki/All-America_Football_Conference" title="All-America Football Conference">All-America Football Conference</a> (AAFC) league charter member, moved to the NFL in 1950 and into <a href="/wiki/Candlestick_Park" title="Candlestick Park">Candlestick Park</a> in 1971. The team will play its home games at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Levi%27s_Stadium&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Levi's Stadium (page does not exist)">Levi's Stadium</a> in nearby <a href="/wiki/Santa_Clara,_California" title="Santa Clara, California">Santa Clara, California</a> in 2014; the team will still be named the "San Francisco 49ers", even though they will be much closer to the city of <a href="/wiki/San_Jose,_California" title="San Jose, California">San Jose</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup> The 49ers have won five <a href="/wiki/Super_Bowl" title="Super Bowl">Super Bowl</a> titles in the 1980s and 1990s behind coaches <a href="/wiki/Bill_Walsh_(American_football_coach)" title="Bill Walsh (American football coach)">Bill Walsh</a> and <a href="/wiki/George_Seifert" title="George Seifert">George Seifert</a>, and stars such as <a href="/wiki/Joe_Montana" title="Joe Montana">Joe Montana</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Steve_Young_(athlete)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Steve Young (athlete) (page does not exist)">Steve Young</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ronnie_Lott" title="Ronnie Lott">Ronnie Lott</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jerry_Rice" title="Jerry Rice">Jerry Rice</a>.
At the collegiate level, the Dons of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=University_of_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="University of San Francisco (page does not exist)">University of San Francisco</a> compete in <a href="/wiki/NCAA" title="NCAA" class="mw-redirect">NCAA</a> <a href="/wiki/NCAA_Division_I" title="NCAA Division I" class="mw-redirect">Division I</a>, where <a href="/wiki/Bill_Russell" title="Bill Russell">Bill Russell</a> guided the program to <a href="/wiki/NCAA_Men%27s_Division_I_Basketball_Championship" title="NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship">basketball championships</a> in 1955 and 1956. The <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_State_University" title="San Francisco State University">San Francisco State</a> Gators and the <a href="/wiki/Academy_of_Art_University" title="Academy of Art University">Academy of Art University</a> Urban Knights compete in <a href="/wiki/NCAA_Division_II" title="NCAA Division II" class="mw-redirect">Division II</a>. AT&amp;T Park has since 2002 hosted an annual post-season <a href="/wiki/College_football" title="College football">college football</a> <a href="/wiki/Bowl_game" title="Bowl game">bowl game</a>, currently named the <a href="/wiki/Fight_Hunger_Bowl" title="Fight Hunger Bowl">Fight Hunger Bowl</a>. In 2011, San Francisco hosted the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_California_Golden_Bears_football_team&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 California Golden Bears football team (page does not exist)">California Golden Bears</a> football team at Candlestick Park and AT&amp;T Park while their home stadium in Berkeley was being renovated.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Candlestick_Park_aerial.jpg" title="File:Candlestick Park aerial.jpg">File:Candlestick Park aerial.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Candlestick_Park" title="Candlestick Park">Candlestick Park</a> hosted the Giants from 1960 to 1999 and the 49ers from 1971 until 2013.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=San_Francisco_Pro-Am_Basketball_League&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San Francisco Pro-Am Basketball League (page does not exist)">San Francisco Pro-Am Basketball League</a> is an important summer league venue for aspiring players to be discovered by talent scouts. Games are held at the 4,000 seat <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kezar_Pavilion&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kezar Pavilion (page does not exist)">Kezar Pavilion</a>. Players from all levels participate with regular appearances by off season NBA professionals.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:USF_WMG.JPG" title="File:USF WMG.JPG">File:USF WMG.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/w/index.php?title=University_of_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="University of San Francisco (page does not exist)">University of San Francisco</a> Dons men's basketball team plays at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=War_Memorial_Gymnasium&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="War Memorial Gymnasium (page does not exist)">War Memorial Gymnasium</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bay_to_Breakers&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bay to Breakers (page does not exist)">Bay to Breakers</a> footrace, held annually since 1912, is best known for colorful costumes and a celebratory community spirit.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=San_Francisco_Marathon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San Francisco Marathon (page does not exist)">San Francisco Marathon</a> attracts more than 21,000 participants.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Escape_from_Alcatraz_(triathlon)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Escape from Alcatraz (triathlon) (page does not exist)">Escape from Alcatraz</a> <a href="/wiki/Triathlon" title="Triathlon">triathlon</a> has, since 1980, attracted 2,000 top professional and amateur triathletes for its annual race.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Club" title="Olympic Club">Olympic Club</a>, founded in 1860, is the oldest <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sports_club&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sports club (page does not exist)">athletic club</a> in the United States. Its private golf course, situated on the border with <a href="/wiki/Daly_City,_California" title="Daly City, California">Daly City</a>, has hosted the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Open_(golf)" title="U.S. Open (golf)">U.S. Open</a> on five occasions. The public <a href="/w/index.php?title=Harding_Park_Golf_Course&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Harding Park Golf Course (page does not exist)">Harding Park Golf Course</a> is an occasional stop on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=PGA_Tour&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="PGA Tour (page does not exist)">PGA Tour</a>. San Francisco will host the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2013_America%27s_Cup&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2013 America's Cup (page does not exist)">2013 America's Cup</a> yacht racing competition.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup>
</p><p>With an ideal climate for outdoor activities, San Francisco has ample resources and opportunities for amateur and participatory sports and recreation. There are more than <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of <a href="/wiki/Segregated_cycle_facilities" title="Segregated cycle facilities">bicycle paths, lanes</a> and bike routes in the city,<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Embarcadero_(San_Francisco)" title="Embarcadero (San Francisco)">Embarcadero</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Marina_Green&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Marina Green (page does not exist)">Marina Green</a> are favored sites for <a href="/wiki/Skateboarding" title="Skateboarding">skateboarding</a>. Extensive public tennis facilities are available in <a href="/wiki/Golden_Gate_Park" title="Golden Gate Park">Golden Gate Park</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dolores_Park" title="Dolores Park">Dolores Park</a>, as well as at smaller neighborhood courts throughout the city. San Francisco residents have often ranked among the fittest in the U.S.<sup id="cite_ref-fitness_125-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fitness-125">[125]</a></sup>
</p><p>Boating, sailing, <a href="/wiki/Windsurfing" title="Windsurfing">windsurfing</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kitesurfing" title="Kitesurfing">kitesurfing</a> are among the popular activities on San Francisco Bay, and the city maintains a yacht harbor in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Marina_District,_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Marina District, San Francisco (page does not exist)">Marina District</a>. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=St._Francis_Yacht_Club&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="St. Francis Yacht Club (page does not exist)">St. Francis Yacht Club</a> and <a href="/wiki/Golden_Gate_Yacht_Club" title="Golden Gate Yacht Club">Golden Gate Yacht Club</a> are located in the Marina Harbor.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup> The South Beach Yacht Club is located next to AT&amp;T Park and <a href="/wiki/Pier_39" title="Pier 39">Pier 39</a> has an extensive marina.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Olympic_Club_18th_hole_lakeside.jpg" title="File:Olympic Club 18th hole lakeside.jpg">File:Olympic Club 18th hole lakeside.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The 18th hole at the <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Club" title="Olympic Club">Olympic Club</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Historic <a href="/w/index.php?title=Aquatic_Park_Historic_District&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aquatic Park Historic District (page does not exist)">Aquatic Park</a> located along the northern San Francisco shore hosts two swimming and rowing clubs.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[131]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=South_End_Rowing_Club&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="South End Rowing Club (page does not exist)">South End Rowing Club</a>, established in 1873, and the Dolphin Club maintain a friendly rivalry between members. Swimmers can be seen daily braving the typically cold bay waters.
</p><p>Amateur men's <a href="/wiki/Soccer" title="Soccer" class="mw-redirect">soccer</a> has been played in San Francisco since 1902 through the <a href="/w/index.php?title=San_Francisco_Soccer_Football_League&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San Francisco Soccer Football League (page does not exist)">San Francisco Soccer Football League</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup> Over 40 teams in 4 divisions play throughout the city between the months of March and November. Premier Division games are played at the 3,500 seat <a href="/w/index.php?title=Boxer_Stadium&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Boxer Stadium (page does not exist)">Boxer Stadium</a>. Amateur women's soccer is played on over 30 teams in the Golden Gate Women's Soccer League.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Cycling_in_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cycling in San Francisco (page does not exist)">Cycling</a> is growing in San Francisco. Annual bicycle counts conducted by the <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Municipal_Transportation_Agency" title="San Francisco Municipal Transportation Agency">Municipal Transportation Agency (MTA)</a> in 2010 showed the number of cyclists at 33 locations had increased 58% from the 2006 baseline counts.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup> The MTA estimates that about 128,000 trips are made by bicycle each day in the city, or 6% of total trips.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup> Improvements in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cycling_infrastructure&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cycling infrastructure (page does not exist)">cycling infrastructure</a> in recent years, including additional bike lanes and parking racks, has made cycling in San Francisco safer and more convenient. Since 2006, San Francisco has received a Bicycle Friendly Community status of "Gold" from the <a href="/wiki/League_of_American_Bicyclists" title="League of American Bicyclists">League of American Bicyclists</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Alcatraz_Island_1,_SF,_CA,_jjron_25.03.2012.jpg" title="File:Alcatraz Island 1, SF, CA, jjron 25.03.2012.jpg">File:Alcatraz Island 1, SF, CA, jjron 25.03.2012.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Alcatraz_Island" title="Alcatraz Island">Alcatraz</a> receives 1.5&#160;million visitors per year.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Tourism, the city's largest private-sector employer,<sup id="cite_ref-tourism-largest-private-sector_137-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tourism-largest-private-sector-137">[137]</a></sup> is the backbone of the San Francisco economy. Its <a href="/w/index.php?title=San_Francisco_in_popular_culture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San Francisco in popular culture (page does not exist)">frequent portrayal</a> in music, film, and popular culture has made the city and its landmarks recognizable worldwide. It is the city where <a href="/wiki/Tony_Bennett" title="Tony Bennett">Tony Bennett</a> "left <a href="/wiki/I_Left_My_Heart_in_San_Francisco" title="I Left My Heart in San Francisco">his heart</a>," where the <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Birdman_of_Alcatraz&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Birdman of Alcatraz (page does not exist)">Birdman of Alcatraz</a></i> spent many of his final years, where <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rice-a-Roni&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rice-a-Roni (page does not exist)">Rice-a-Roni</a><sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[138]</a></sup> was said to be the favorite treat, and where <a href="/wiki/Full_House" title="Full House">Full House</a>, a popular American sitcom was set. San Francisco attracts the fifth-highest number of foreign tourists of any city in the U.S.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Update_after&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Update after (page does not exist)">Template:Update after</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-TravelandTourism_139-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TravelandTourism-139">[139]</a></sup> ranks 44th out of the 100 most visited cities worldwide,<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Update_after&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Update after (page does not exist)">Template:Update after</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-euromonitor.com_140-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-euromonitor.com-140">[140]</a></sup> and claims <a href="/wiki/Pier_39" title="Pier 39">Pier 39</a> near <a href="/wiki/Fisherman%27s_Wharf,_San_Francisco" title="Fisherman's Wharf, San Francisco">Fisherman's Wharf</a> as the third-most popular tourist attraction in the nation.<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[141]</a></sup> More than 16.5&#160;million visitors arrived in San Francisco in 2012, injecting $8.9&#160;billion into the economy.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup> With a large hotel infrastructure and a world-class convention facility in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Moscone_Center&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Moscone Center (page does not exist)">Moscone Center</a>, San Francisco is also among the top-ten North American destinations for conventions and conferences.<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[143]</a></sup> In a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Euromonitor_International&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Euromonitor International (page does not exist)">Euromonitor International</a> ranking of top city destinations, San Francisco was ranked the 33rd most visited city in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-euromonitor.com_140-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-euromonitor.com-140">[140]</a></sup>
</p><p>The legacy of the <a href="/wiki/California_Gold_Rush" title="California Gold Rush">California Gold Rush</a> turned San Francisco into the principal banking and finance center of the <a href="/wiki/West_Coast_of_the_United_States" title="West Coast of the United States">West Coast</a> in the early twentieth century. <a href="/wiki/Montgomery_Street" title="Montgomery Street">Montgomery Street</a> in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Financial_District_(San_Francisco)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Financial District (San Francisco) (page does not exist)">Financial District</a> became known as the "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Wall_Street_of_the_West&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wall Street of the West (page does not exist)">Wall Street of the West</a>," home to the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Reserve_Bank_of_San_Francisco" title="Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco">Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wells_Fargo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wells Fargo (page does not exist)">Wells Fargo</a> corporate headquarters, and the site of the now-defunct <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Exchange" title="Pacific Exchange">Pacific Coast Stock Exchange</a>. <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_America" title="Bank of America">Bank of America</a>, a pioneer in making banking services accessible to the middle class, was founded in San Francisco and in the 1960s, built the landmark modern skyscraper at <a href="/wiki/555_California_Street" title="555 California Street">555 California Street</a> for its corporate headquarters. Many large financial institutions, multinational banks and venture capital firms are based in or have regional headquarters in the city. With over 30 international financial institutions,<sup id="cite_ref-CityData.com_144-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CityData.com-144">[144]</a></sup> seven <a href="/wiki/Fortune_500" title="Fortune 500">Fortune 500</a> companies,<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup> and a large support infrastructure of professional services—including law, public relations, <a href="/w/index.php?title=San_Francisco_architecture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San Francisco architecture (page does not exist)">architecture</a> and design—also with significant presence in the city, San Francisco is designated as an <a href="/wiki/Global_city" title="Global city">Alpha(-) World City</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[146]</a></sup> San Francisco ranks 18th in the world's <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_cities_by_GDP&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of cities by GDP (page does not exist)">top producing cities</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Global_Financial_Centres_Index&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Global Financial Centres Index (page does not exist)">12th place</a> in the top twenty global financial centers.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:SF_California_Street_USA.jpg" title="File:SF California Street USA.jpg">File:SF California Street USA.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The Financial District down California Street.</div></div></div>
<p>Since the 1990s, San Francisco's economy has increasingly become tied to <a href="/wiki/San_Jose,_California" title="San Jose, California">San Jose</a> and <a href="/wiki/Silicon_Valley" title="Silicon Valley">Silicon Valley</a>, its neighbors to the south, sharing the need for highly educated workers with specialized skills.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup> San Francisco became an epicenter of the <a href="/wiki/Dot-com_bubble" title="Dot-com bubble">Dot-Com bubble</a> of the 1990s, and the subsequent <a href="/wiki/Web_2.0" title="Web 2.0">Web 2.0</a> boom of the late 2000s. Many popular and prominent Internet companies and "<a href="/wiki/Startup_company" title="Startup company">start-ups</a>" such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Craigslist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Craigslist (page does not exist)">Craigslist</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Twitter&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Twitter (page does not exist)">Twitter</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Square,_Inc.&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Square, Inc. (page does not exist)">Square</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Zynga&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Zynga (page does not exist)">Zynga</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Salesforce.com&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Salesforce.com (page does not exist)">Salesforce.com</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Airbnb&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Airbnb (page does not exist)">Airbnb</a>, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wikimedia_Foundation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wikimedia Foundation (page does not exist)">Wikimedia Foundation</a> among others have established their head offices in San Francisco.
</p><p>San Francisco has been positioning itself as a <a href="/wiki/Biotechnology" title="Biotechnology">biotechnology</a> and <a href="/wiki/Biomedical" title="Biomedical" class="mw-redirect">biomedical</a> hub and research center. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mission_Bay,_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mission Bay, San Francisco (page does not exist)">Mission Bay</a> neighborhood, site of a second campus of <a href="/w/index.php?title=University_of_California-San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="University of California-San Francisco (page does not exist)">UCSF</a>, fosters a budding industry and serves as headquarters of the <a href="/wiki/California_Institute_for_Regenerative_Medicine" title="California Institute for Regenerative Medicine">California Institute for Regenerative Medicine</a>, the public agency funding <a href="/wiki/Stem_cell_research" title="Stem cell research" class="mw-redirect">stem cell research</a> programs statewide. As of 2009, there were 1,800 full-time biochemists and biophysicists employed in San Francisco, with an annual mean wage of $92,620.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup>
</p><p>Small businesses with fewer than 10 employees and self-employed firms make up 85% of city establishments as lately, it has been particularly popular with entrepreneurs establishing "start-up" companies.<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[150]</a></sup> The number of San Franciscans employed by firms of more than 1,000 employees has fallen by half since 1977.<sup id="cite_ref-SFEconomicStrategy_91-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SFEconomicStrategy-91">[91]</a></sup> The successful penetration of national <a href="/w/index.php?title=Big_box&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Big box (page does not exist)">big box</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_retail&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Formula retail (page does not exist)">formula retail</a> chains into the city has been made intentionally difficult by political and civic consensus. In an effort to buoy small privately owned businesses in San Francisco and preserve the unique retail personality of the city, the Small Business Commission supports a publicity campaign to keep a larger share of retail dollars in the local economy,<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup> and the Board of Supervisors has used the planning code to limit the neighborhoods where formula retail establishments can set up shop,<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[152]</a></sup> an effort affirmed by San Francisco voters.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[153]</a></sup>
</p><p>In August 2013, <i><a href="/wiki/Forbes" title="Forbes">Forbes</a></i> named San Francisco among its list of Best Places for Business and Careers.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[154]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>, the city has had a resurgence of apparel manufacturing industry due to a variety of factors.<sup id="cite_ref-Burgeoning_Manufacturing_Sector_Grows_in_San_Francisco_155-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Burgeoning_Manufacturing_Sector_Grows_in_San_Francisco-155">[155]</a></sup>
</p><p>The top employer in the city is the city government itself, employing 6.25% (26,000+ people) of the city's population, followed by <a href="/wiki/University_of_California,_San_Francisco" title="University of California, San Francisco">University of California, San Francisco</a>. Third, at 2.04% (8,000+ people), is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wells_Fargo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wells Fargo (page does not exist)">Wells Fargo</a>, the largest private-sector employer.<sup id="cite_ref-cafr2009_156-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cafr2009-156">[156]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Law_and_government">Law and government</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
San Francisco—officially known as the City and County of San Francisco—is a <a href="/wiki/Consolidated_city-county" title="Consolidated city-county">consolidated city-county</a>, a status it has held since the 1856 secession of what is now <a href="/wiki/San_Mateo_County,_California" title="San Mateo County, California">San Mateo County</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Coy_1919_409_6-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Coy_1919_409-6">[6]</a></sup> It is the only such consolidation in California.<sup id="cite_ref-CityCounty_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CityCounty-1">[1]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mayor_of_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mayor of San Francisco (page does not exist)">mayor</a> is also the county executive, and the county <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Board_of_Supervisors" title="San Francisco Board of Supervisors">Board of Supervisors</a> acts as the <a href="/wiki/City_council" title="City council">city council</a>. The government of San Francisco is a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Charter_city&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Charter city (page does not exist)">charter city</a> and is constituted of two co-equal branches. The executive branch is headed by the mayor and includes other citywide elected and appointed officials as well as the civil service. The 11-member Board of Supervisors, the legislative branch, is headed by a president and is responsible for passing laws and budgets, though San Franciscans also make use of <a href="/wiki/Initiative" title="Initiative">direct ballot initiatives</a> to pass legislation.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:SFCityHall.png" title="File:SFCityHall.png">File:SFCityHall.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_City_Hall" title="San Francisco City Hall">San Francisco City Hall</a></div></div></div>
<p>The members of the Board of Supervisors are elected as representatives of specific districts within the city.<sup id="cite_ref-SF_Gov_Supervisor_Districts_157-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SF_Gov_Supervisor_Districts-157">[157]</a></sup> Upon the death or resignation of mayor, the President of the Board of Supervisors becomes acting mayor until the full Board elects an interim replacement for the remainder of the term. In 1978, <a href="/wiki/Dianne_Feinstein" title="Dianne Feinstein">Dianne Feinstein</a> assumed the office following the assassination of <a href="/wiki/George_Moscone" title="George Moscone">George Moscone</a> and was later selected by the Board to finish the term. In 2011, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Edwin_M._Lee&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Edwin M. Lee (page does not exist)">Edwin M. Lee</a> was selected by the Board to finish the term of <a href="/wiki/Gavin_Newsom" title="Gavin Newsom">Gavin Newsom</a>, who resigned to take office as <a href="/wiki/Lieutenant_Governor_of_California" title="Lieutenant Governor of California">Lieutenant Governor of California</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[158]</a></sup>
</p><p>Because of its unique city-county status, local government exercises jurisdiction over property that would otherwise be located outside of its corporation limit. <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_International_Airport" title="San Francisco International Airport">San Francisco International Airport</a>, though located in <a href="/wiki/San_Mateo_County" title="San Mateo County" class="mw-redirect">San Mateo County</a>, is owned and operated by the City and County of San Francisco. San Francisco also has a county jail complex located in San Mateo County, in an <a href="/wiki/Unincorporated_area" title="Unincorporated area">unincorporated area</a> adjacent to <a href="/wiki/San_Bruno,_California" title="San Bruno, California">San Bruno</a>. San Francisco was also granted a perpetual leasehold over the <a href="/wiki/Hetch_Hetchy_Valley" title="Hetch Hetchy Valley" class="mw-redirect">Hetch Hetchy Valley</a> and <a href="/wiki/Drainage_basin" title="Drainage basin">watershed</a> in <a href="/wiki/Yosemite_National_Park" title="Yosemite National Park">Yosemite National Park</a> by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Raker_Act&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Raker Act (page does not exist)">Raker Act</a> in 1913.<sup id="cite_ref-CityCounty_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CityCounty-1">[1]</a></sup>
</p><p>San Francisco serves as the regional hub for many arms of the federal bureaucracy, including the <a href="/wiki/Ninth_Circuit_U.S._Court_of_Appeals" title="Ninth Circuit U.S. Court of Appeals" class="mw-redirect">U.S. Court of Appeals</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Reserve_Bank_of_San_Francisco" title="Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco">Federal Reserve Bank</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Mint" title="United States Mint">U.S. Mint</a>. Until <a href="/w/index.php?title=Base_Realignment_and_Closure&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Base Realignment and Closure (page does not exist)">decommissioning</a> in the early 1990s, the city had major military installations at the <a href="/wiki/Presidio_of_San_Francisco" title="Presidio of San Francisco">Presidio</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Treasure_Island,_California&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Treasure Island, California (page does not exist)">Treasure Island</a>, and <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Naval_Shipyard" title="San Francisco Naval Shipyard">Hunters Point</a>—a legacy still reflected in the annual celebration of <a href="/wiki/Fleet_Week" title="Fleet Week">Fleet Week</a>. The State of California uses San Francisco as the home of the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_California" title="Supreme Court of California">state supreme court</a> and other state agencies. Foreign governments maintain more than seventy consulates in San Francisco.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[159]</a></sup>
</p><p>The municipal budget for fiscal year 2013–14 was $7.9&#160;billion.<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[160]</a></sup> The city employs around 27,000 workers.<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">[161]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Historical_populations&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Historical populations (page does not exist)">Template:Historical populations</a>
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_Census&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 United States Census (page does not exist)">2010 United States Census</a><sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">[162]</a></sup> reported that San Francisco had a population of 805,235. The <a href="/wiki/Population_density" title="Population density">population density</a> was 17,160 per square mile (6,632/km<sup>2</sup>). The ethnic makeup and population of San Francisco included: 390,387 <a href="/wiki/White_(U.S._Census)" title="White (U.S. Census)" class="mw-redirect">Whites</a> (48.1%), 267,915 <a href="/wiki/Asian_(U.S._Census)" title="Asian (U.S. Census)" class="mw-redirect">Asians</a> (33.3%), 48,870 <a href="/wiki/African_American_(U.S._Census)" title="African American (U.S. Census)" class="mw-redirect">African Americans</a> (6.1%), 4,024 <a href="/wiki/Native_American_(U.S._Census)" title="Native American (U.S. Census)" class="mw-redirect">Native Americans</a> (0.5%), 3,359 <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Islander_(U.S._Census)" title="Pacific Islander (U.S. Census)" class="mw-redirect">Pacific Islanders</a> (0.4%), 53,021 from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Race_(United_States_Census)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Race (United States Census) (page does not exist)">other races</a> (6.6%), and 37,659 from two or more races (4.7%). There were 121,744 <a href="/wiki/Hispanic_(U.S._Census)" title="Hispanic (U.S. Census)" class="mw-redirect">Hispanics</a> or <a href="/wiki/Latino_(U.S._Census)" title="Latino (U.S. Census)" class="mw-redirect">Latinos</a> of any race (15.1%). Whites not of Hispanic origin made up 41.9% of the population, making San Francisco a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Majority-minority&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Majority-minority (page does not exist)">majority-minority</a> city, though non-Hispanic whites form a plurality of the population.
</p><p>The Census reported that 780,971 people (97.0% of the population) lived in households, 18,902 (2.3%) lived in non-institutionalized group quarters, and 5,362 (0.7%) were institutionalized. The U.S. Census Bureau estimates San Francisco's population increased to 825,863 as of July 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-2012-pop-estimate_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2012-pop-estimate-4">[4]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2010, residents of <a href="/wiki/Chinese_American" title="Chinese American">Chinese ethnicity</a> constituted the largest single ethnic minority group in San Francisco at 21.4% of the population; the other Asian groups are <a href="/wiki/Filipino_American" title="Filipino American">Filipinos</a> (4.5%), <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_American" title="Vietnamese American">Vietnamese</a> (1.6%), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese American (page does not exist)">Japanese</a> (1.3%), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indian American (page does not exist)">Asian Indians</a> (1.2%), <a href="/wiki/Korean_American" title="Korean American">Koreans</a> (1.2%), <a href="/wiki/Thai_American" title="Thai American">Thais</a> (0.3%), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Burmese_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Burmese American (page does not exist)">Burmese</a> (0.2%), <a href="/wiki/Cambodian_American" title="Cambodian American">Cambodians</a> (0.2%), and both <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indonesian_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indonesian American (page does not exist)">Indonesians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Laotian_American" title="Laotian American">Laotians</a> make up less than 0.1% of the city's population.<sup id="cite_ref-Census_2010-GCT-PH1_163-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Census_2010-GCT-PH1-163">[163]</a></sup>
</p><p>There were 345,811 households, out of which 63,577 (18.4%) had children under the age of 18 living in them, 109,437 (31.6%) were <a href="/wiki/Marriage" title="Marriage">opposite-sex married couples</a> living together, 28,844 (8.3%) had a female householder with no spouse present, 12,748 (3.7%) had a male householder with no spouse present. There were 21,677 (6.3%) <a href="/wiki/POSSLQ" title="POSSLQ">unmarried opposite-sex partnerships</a>, and 10,384 (3.0%) <a href="/w/index.php?title=Same-sex_partnerships&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Same-sex partnerships (page does not exist)">same-sex married couples or partnerships</a>. 133,366 households (38.6%) were made up of individuals and 34,234 (9.9%) had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.26. There were 151,029 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Family_(U.S._Census)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Family (U.S. Census) (page does not exist)">families</a> (43.7% of all households); the average family size was 3.11.
</p><p>The age distribution of the city was as follows:107,524 people (13.4%) under the age of 18, 77,664 people (9.6%) aged 18 to 24, 301,802 people (37.5%) aged 25 to 44, 208,403 people (25.9%) aged 45 to 64, and 109,842 people (13.6%) who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 38.5 years. For every 100 females there were 102.9 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 102.8 males.
</p><p>There were 376,942 housing units, at an average density of 1,625.5 per square mile (627.6/km<sup>2</sup>), of which 123,646 (35.8%) were owner-occupied, and 222,165 (64.2%) were occupied by renters. The homeowner vacancy rate was 2.3%; the rental vacancy rate was 5.4%. 327,985 people (40.7% of the population) lived in owner-occupied housing units and 452,986 people (56.3%) lived in rental housing units.
</p><p>With over 17,000 people per square mile, San Francisco is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_United_States_cities_by_population_density&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of United States cities by population density (page does not exist)">second-most densely populated</a> major American city (among cities greater than 200,000 population).<sup id="cite_ref-SF_Population_Density_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SF_Population_Density-3">[3]</a></sup> San Francisco is the traditional focal point of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=San_Francisco_Bay_Area&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San Francisco Bay Area (page does not exist)">San Francisco Bay Area</a> and forms part of the San Francisco-Oakland-<a href="/wiki/Fremont,_California" title="Fremont, California">Fremont</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Metropolitan_Statistical_Area&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Metropolitan Statistical Area (page does not exist)">Metropolitan Statistical Area</a> and the greater <a href="/wiki/San_Jose,_California" title="San Jose, California">San Jose</a>-San Francisco-<a href="/wiki/Oakland,_California" title="Oakland, California">Oakland</a> <a href="/wiki/Combined_Statistical_Area" title="Combined Statistical Area">Combined Statistical Area</a> (CSA) whose population is over seven million, making it the fifth largest in the United States as of the 2000 Census.<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[164]</a></sup>
</p><p>Native-born Californians form a relatively small percentage of the city's population: only 37.7% of its residents were born in California, while 25.2% were born in a different U.S. state. More than a third of city residents (35.6%) were born outside the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-SF_QuickFacts_165-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SF_QuickFacts-165">[165]</a></sup>
</p><p>The population of Chinese ancestry is most heavily concentrated in Chinatown, <a href="/wiki/Sunset_District" title="Sunset District" class="mw-redirect">Sunset District</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Richmond_District,_San_Francisco" title="Richmond District, San Francisco">Richmond District</a>, whereas Filipinos are most concentrated in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Crocker-Amazon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Crocker-Amazon (page does not exist)">Crocker-Amazon</a> (which is continuous with the Filipino community of <a href="/wiki/Daly_City" title="Daly City" class="mw-redirect">Daly City</a>, the city with one of the highest concentrations of Filipinos in North America), as well as in <a href="/wiki/South_of_Market" title="South of Market" class="mw-redirect">SoMa</a>. After declining in the 1970s and 1980s, the Filipino community in the city has experienced a significant resurgence. The San Francisco Bay Area is home to over 382,950 Filipino Americans, one of the largest communities of Filipinos outside of the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Census_2010-GCT-PH1_163-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Census_2010-GCT-PH1-163">[163]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[166]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tenderloin,_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tenderloin, San Francisco (page does not exist)">Tenderloin District</a> is home to a large portion of the city's Vietnamese population as well as businesses and restaurants, which is known as the city's Little Saigon. Koreans and Japanese have a large presence in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Western_Addition&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Western Addition (page does not exist)">Western Addition</a>, which is where the city's <a href="/wiki/Japantown,_San_Francisco" title="Japantown, San Francisco">Japantown</a> is located. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pacific_Islander_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pacific Islander American (page does not exist)">Pacific Islander</a> population is 0.4% (0.8% including those with partial ancestry). Over half of the Pacific Islander population is of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Samoan_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Samoan American (page does not exist)">Samoan</a> descent, with residence in the <a href="/wiki/Bayview-Hunters_Point" title="Bayview-Hunters Point" class="mw-redirect">Bayview-Hunters Point</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Visitacion_Valley&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Visitacion Valley (page does not exist)">Visitacion Valley</a> areas; Pacific Islanders make up more than three percent of the population in both communities.<sup id="cite_ref-Census_2010-GCT-PH1_163-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Census_2010-GCT-PH1-163">[163]</a></sup>
</p><p>San Francisco has a <a href="/wiki/Minority-majority" title="Minority-majority" class="mw-redirect">minority-majority</a> population, as non-Hispanic <a href="/w/index.php?title=White_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="White American (page does not exist)">whites</a> comprise less than half of the population, 41.9%, down from 92.5% in 1940.<sup id="cite_ref-census_23-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-census-23">[23]</a></sup> The principal <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hispanics_in_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hispanics in the United States (page does not exist)">Hispanic</a> groups in the city were those of <a href="/wiki/Mexican_American" title="Mexican American">Mexican</a> (7.4%), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Salvadoran_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Salvadoran American (page does not exist)">Salvadoran</a> (2.0%), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nicaraguan_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nicaraguan American (page does not exist)">Nicaraguan</a> (0.9%), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Guatemalan_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Guatemalan American (page does not exist)">Guatemalan</a> (0.8%), and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Stateside_Puerto_Rican&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Stateside Puerto Rican (page does not exist)">Puerto Rican</a> (0.5%), ancestry. The Hispanic population is most heavily concentrated in the <a href="/wiki/Mission_District,_San_Francisco" title="Mission District, San Francisco">Mission District</a>, Tenderloin District, and <a href="/wiki/Excelsior_District,_San_Francisco" title="Excelsior District, San Francisco">Excelsior District</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-interactivemap_167-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-interactivemap-167">[167]</a></sup>
San Francisco's <a href="/wiki/Black_American" title="Black American" class="mw-redirect">African American</a> population has declined in recent decades,<sup id="cite_ref-census_23-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-census-23">[23]</a></sup> from 13.4% of the population in 1970 to 6.1%.<sup id="cite_ref-SF_QuickFacts_165-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SF_QuickFacts-165">[165]</a></sup> The current percentage of African Americans in San Francisco is similar to that of the state of California;<sup id="cite_ref-SF_QuickFacts_165-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SF_QuickFacts-165">[165]</a></sup> conversely, the city's percentage of Hispanic residents is less than half of that of the state. The majority of the city's black population reside within the neighborhoods of <a href="/wiki/Bayview-Hunters_Point,_San_Francisco" title="Bayview-Hunters Point, San Francisco">Bayview-Hunters Point</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Visitacion_Valley,_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Visitacion Valley, San Francisco (page does not exist)">Visitacion Valley</a> in southeastern San Francisco, and in the <a href="/wiki/Fillmore_District,_San_Francisco" title="Fillmore District, San Francisco">Fillmore District</a> in the northeastern part of the city.<sup id="cite_ref-interactivemap_167-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-interactivemap-167">[167]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the 2005 American Community Survey, San Francisco has the highest percentage of gay and lesbian individuals of any of the 50 largest U.S. cities, at 15.4%.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[168]</a></sup> San Francisco also has the highest percentage of same-sex households of any American county, with the Bay Area having a higher concentration than any other <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_area" title="Metropolitan area">metropolitan area</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-gaystats_169-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gaystats-169">[169]</a></sup>
</p><p>Of all major cities, San Francisco has the second-highest percentage of residents with a college degree, behind only <a href="/w/index.php?title=Seattle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Seattle (page does not exist)">Seattle</a>. Over 44% of adults within the city limits have a bachelor's or higher degree.<sup id="cite_ref-Bizjournals_170-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bizjournals-170">[170]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/USA_Today" title="USA Today">USA Today</a></i> reported that Rob Pitingolo, a researcher who measured college graduates per square mile, found that San Francisco had the highest rate at 7,031 per square mile, or over 344,000 total graduates in the city's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-USA_Today_171-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-USA_Today-171">[171]</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="float: right; clear: both;">

<tr>
<th colspan="6"> Income in 2011
</th></tr>
<tr>
<th scope="row" style="text-align: left;"> Per capita income<sup id="cite_ref-US-CB-B19301_172-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-US-CB-B19301-172">[172]</a></sup>
</th>
<td colspan="2"> $46,777
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th scope="row" style="text-align: left;"> Median household income<sup id="cite_ref-US-CB-B19013_173-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-US-CB-B19013-173">[173]</a></sup>
</th>
<td colspan="2"> $72,947
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th scope="row" style="text-align: left;"> Median family income<sup id="cite_ref-US-CB-B19113_174-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-US-CB-B19113-174">[174]</a></sup>
</th>
<td colspan="2"> $87,329
</td></tr></table>
