<p>San Francisco ranks third of American cities in median household income<sup id="cite_ref-Census_ACS_2003_175-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Census_ACS_2003-175">[175]</a></sup> with a 2007 value of $65,519.<sup id="cite_ref-SF_QuickFacts_165-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SF_QuickFacts-165">[165]</a></sup> Median family income is $81,136,<sup id="cite_ref-SF_QuickFacts_165-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SF_QuickFacts-165">[165]</a></sup> and San Francisco ranks 8th of major cities worldwide in the number of billionaires known to be living within city limits.<sup id="cite_ref-Billionaires_in_San_Francisco_176-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Billionaires_in_San_Francisco-176">[176]</a></sup> Following a national trend, an emigration of middle-class families is contributing to widening income disparity<sup id="cite_ref-MiddleClass_90-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MiddleClass-90">[90]</a></sup> and has left the city with a lower proportion of children, 14.5%, than any other large American city.<sup id="cite_ref-ChildPopulation_177-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ChildPopulation-177">[177]</a></sup>
</p><p>The city's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Poverty_rate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Poverty rate (page does not exist)">poverty rate</a> is 11.8% and the number of families in poverty stands at 7.4%, both lower than the national average.<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[178]</a></sup> The unemployment rate stands at 5.6% as of September 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[179]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Homelessness&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Homelessness (page does not exist)">Homelessness</a> has been a chronic and controversial problem for San Francisco since the early 1980s. The homeless population is estimated to be 13,500 with 6,500 living on the streets.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[180]</a></sup> The city is believed to have the highest number of homeless inhabitants per capita of any major U.S. city.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[181]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[182]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Crime_rate" title="Crime rate" class="mw-redirect">Rates</a> of reported violent and property crimes for 2009 (736 and 4,262 incidents per 100,000 residents, respectively)<sup id="cite_ref-SFCrimeStats_183-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SFCrimeStats-183">[183]</a></sup> are slightly lower than for similarly sized U.S. cities.<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">[184]</a></sup>
</p>
<table>

<tr>
<td align="left">

</td></tr></table>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3>
<p>As of 2010, 54.58% (411,728) of San Francisco residents age 5 and older spoke <a href="/w/index.php?title=English_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="English language (page does not exist)">English</a> at home as a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Primary_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Primary language (page does not exist)">primary language</a>, while 18.60% (140,302) spoke <a href="/wiki/Chinese_language" title="Chinese language">Chinese</a>, 11.68% (88,147) <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a>, 3.42% (25,767) <a href="/wiki/Tagalog_language" title="Tagalog language">Tagalog</a>, 1.86% (14,017) <a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian</a>, 1.45% (10,939) <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_language" title="Vietnamese language">Vietnamese</a>, 1.05% (7,895) <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">French</a>, 0.90% (6,777) <a href="/wiki/Japanese_language" title="Japanese language">Japanese</a>, 0.88% (6,624) <a href="/wiki/Korean_language" title="Korean language">Korean</a>, 0.56% (4,215) <a href="/wiki/German_language" title="German language">German</a>, 0.53% (3,995) <a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">Italian</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Islands" title="Pacific Islands">Pacific Islander languages</a> were spoken as a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Main_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Main language (page does not exist)">main language</a> by 0.47% (3,535) of the population over the age of five. In total, 45.42% (342,693) of San Francisco's population age 5 and older spoke a <a href="/wiki/Mother_language" title="Mother language" class="mw-redirect">mother language</a> other than English.<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">[186]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Crime">Crime</span></h3>
<p>The following table includes the number of incidents reported and the rate per 1,000 persons for each type of offense.
</p>
<table class="wikitable collapsible collapsed">

<tr>
<th colspan="3"> Population and crime rates
</th></tr>
<tr>
<th scope="row" style="text-align: left;"> Population<sup id="cite_ref-FBI-UCR-T8_187-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FBI-UCR-T8-187">[187]</a></sup>
</th>
<td colspan="2"> 820,363
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th scope="row" style="text-align: left;"> Violent crime<sup id="cite_ref-FBI-UCR-T8_187-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FBI-UCR-T8-187">[187]</a></sup>
</th>
<td> 5,777 </td>
<td> 7.04
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th scope="row" style="text-align: left;"> &#160;&#160;Murder and nonnegligent manslaughter<sup id="cite_ref-FBI-UCR-T8_187-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FBI-UCR-T8-187">[187]</a></sup>
</th>
<td> 69 </td>
<td> 0.08
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th scope="row" style="text-align: left;"> &#160;&#160;Forcible rape<sup id="cite_ref-FBI-UCR-T8_187-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FBI-UCR-T8-187">[187]</a></sup>
</th>
<td> 108 </td>
<td> 0.13
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th scope="row" style="text-align: left;"> &#160;&#160;Robbery<sup id="cite_ref-FBI-UCR-T8_187-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FBI-UCR-T8-187">[187]</a></sup>
</th>
<td> 3,484 </td>
<td> 4.25
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th scope="row" style="text-align: left;"> &#160;&#160;Aggravated assault<sup id="cite_ref-FBI-UCR-T8_187-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FBI-UCR-T8-187">[187]</a></sup>
</th>
<td> 2,116 </td>
<td> 2.58
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th scope="row" style="text-align: left;"> Property crime<sup id="cite_ref-FBI-UCR-T8_187-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FBI-UCR-T8-187">[187]</a></sup>
</th>
<td> 38,898 </td>
<td> 47.42
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th scope="row" style="text-align: left;"> &#160;&#160;Burglary<sup id="cite_ref-FBI-UCR-T8_187-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FBI-UCR-T8-187">[187]</a></sup>
</th>
<td> 5,317 </td>
<td> 6.48
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th scope="row" style="text-align: left;"> &#160;&#160;Larceny-theft<sup id="cite_ref-FBI-UCR-T8_187-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FBI-UCR-T8-187">[187]</a></sup>
</th>
<td> 28,242 </td>
<td> 34.43
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th scope="row" style="text-align: left;"> &#160;&#160;Motor vehicle theft<sup id="cite_ref-FBI-UCR-T8_187-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FBI-UCR-T8-187">[187]</a></sup>
</th>
<td> 5,339 </td>
<td> 6.51
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th scope="row" style="text-align: left;"> Arson<sup id="cite_ref-FBI-UCR-T8_187-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FBI-UCR-T8-187">[187]</a></sup>
</th>
<td> 207 </td>
<td> 0.25
</td></tr></table>
<p>In 2011, 50 murders were reported, which is 6.1 per 100,000 people.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[188]</a></sup> There were about 134 rapes, 3,142 robberies, and about 2,139 assaults. There were about 4,469 burglaries, 25,100 thefts, and 4,210 motor vehicle thefts.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">[189]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tenderloin,_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tenderloin, San Francisco (page does not exist)">Tenderloin</a> area has the highest crime rate in San Francisco: 70% of the city's violent crimes, and around one-fourth of the city's murders, occur in this neighborhood. The Tenderloin also sees high rates of homelessness, drug abuse, gang violence, and prostitution.<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">[190]</a></sup> Another area with high crime rates is the <a href="/wiki/Bayview-Hunters_Point,_San_Francisco" title="Bayview-Hunters Point, San Francisco">Bayview-Hunters Point</a> area. Homelessness is also a growing problem in the city.<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[191]</a></sup>
</p><p>Several street gangs operate in the city, including <a href="/w/index.php?title=MS-13&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="MS-13 (page does not exist)">MS-13</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">[192]</a></sup> and to some extent the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Crips&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Crips (page does not exist)">Crips</a> in Bayview - Hunters-Point.<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[193]</a></sup> There is a presence of Asian gangs in Chinatown. In 1977, an ongoing rivalry between two Chinese gangs led to a <a href="/wiki/Golden_Dragon_massacre" title="Golden Dragon massacre">shooting attack at a restaurant in Chinatown</a>, which left 5 people dead and 11 wounded. None of the victims in this attack were gang members. Five members of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Joe_Boys&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Joe Boys (page does not exist)">Joe Boys</a> gang were arrested and convicted of the crime.<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[194]</a></sup> In 1990, a gang-related shooting killed one man and wounded six others outside a nightclub near Chinatown.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[195]</a></sup> In 1998, six teenagers were shot and wounded at the Chinese Playground; a 16-year-old boy was subsequently arrested.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[196]</a></sup>
</p><p>The city is mainly patrolled by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=San_Francisco_Police_Department&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San Francisco Police Department (page does not exist)">San Francisco Police Department</a>. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=San_Francisco_Sheriff%27s_Department&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San Francisco Sheriff's Department (page does not exist)">San Francisco Sheriff's Department</a>, <a href="/wiki/BART_Police" title="BART Police">BART Police</a> (public transit only), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amtrak_Police&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Amtrak Police (page does not exist)">Amtrak Police</a>, <a href="/wiki/California_Highway_Patrol" title="California Highway Patrol">California Highway Patrol</a> and many other local, state, and federal agencies perform law enforcement tasks in the city.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Colleges_and_universities">Colleges and universities</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Lone_Mountain_Campus.jpg" title="File:Lone Mountain Campus.jpg">File:Lone Mountain Campus.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The Lone Mountain Campus of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=University_of_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="University of San Francisco (page does not exist)">University of San Francisco</a>.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The <a href="/wiki/University_of_California,_San_Francisco" title="University of California, San Francisco">University of California, San Francisco</a> is the sole campus of the <a href="/wiki/University_of_California" title="University of California">University of California system</a> entirely dedicated to graduate education in health and biomedical sciences. It is ranked among the top-five medical schools in the United States<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[197]</a></sup> and operates the <a href="/w/index.php?title=UCSF_Medical_Center&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="UCSF Medical Center (page does not exist)">UCSF Medical Center</a>, which ranks among the top 15 hospitals in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">[198]</a></sup> UCSF is a major local employer, second in size only to the city and county government.<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[199]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">[200]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[201]</a></sup> A <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mission_Bay,_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mission Bay, San Francisco (page does not exist)">Mission Bay</a> campus was opened in 2003, complementing its original facility in <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_hills_in_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of hills in San Francisco (page does not exist)">Parnassus Heights</a>. It contains research space and facilities to foster biotechnology and life sciences entrepreneurship and will double the size of UCSF's research enterprise.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[202]</a></sup> All in all, UCSF operates 20 facilities across San Francisco.<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">[203]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/University_of_California,_Hastings_College_of_the_Law" title="University of California, Hastings College of the Law">University of California, Hastings College of the Law</a>, founded in <a href="/wiki/Civic_Center,_San_Francisco" title="Civic Center, San Francisco">Civic Center</a> in 1878, is the oldest law school in California and claims more judges on the state bench than any other institution.<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">[204]</a></sup>
San Francisco's two University of California institutions have recently formed an official affiliation in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=UCSF/UC_Hastings_Consortium_on_Law,_Science_%26_Health_Policy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="UCSF/UC Hastings Consortium on Law, Science &amp; Health Policy (page does not exist)">UCSF/UC Hastings Consortium on Law, Science &amp; Health Policy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">[205]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_State_University" title="San Francisco State University">San Francisco State University</a> is part of the <a href="/wiki/California_State_University" title="California State University">California State University</a> system and is located near <a href="/wiki/Lake_Merced" title="Lake Merced">Lake Merced</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-sfsu_206-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sfsu-206">[206]</a></sup> The school has approximately 30,000 students and awards undergraduate, master's and doctoral degrees in more than 100 disciplines.<sup id="cite_ref-sfsu_206-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sfsu-206">[206]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/City_College_of_San_Francisco" title="City College of San Francisco">City College of San Francisco</a>, with its main facility in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ingleside,_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ingleside, San Francisco (page does not exist)">Ingleside</a> district, is one of the largest two-year <a href="/wiki/Community_college" title="Community college">community colleges</a> in the country. It has an enrollment of about 100,000 students and offers an extensive continuing education program.<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[207]</a></sup>
</p><p>Founded in 1855, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=University_of_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="University of San Francisco (page does not exist)">University of San Francisco</a>, a private <a href="/wiki/Society_of_Jesus" title="Society of Jesus">Jesuit</a> university located on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lone_Mountain_(California)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lone Mountain (California) (page does not exist)">Lone Mountain</a>, is the oldest institution of higher education in San Francisco and one of the oldest universities established west of the Mississippi River.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[208]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Golden_Gate_University" title="Golden Gate University">Golden Gate University</a> is a private, nonsectarian, coeducational university formed in 1901 and located in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Financial_District_(San_Francisco)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Financial District (San Francisco) (page does not exist)">Financial District</a>. It is primarily a post-graduate institution focused on professional training in law and business, with smaller undergraduate programs linked to its graduate and professional schools.
</p><p>With an enrollment of 13,000 students, the <a href="/wiki/Academy_of_Art_University" title="Academy of Art University">Academy of Art University</a> is the largest institute of art and design in the nation.<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[209]</a></sup> Founded in 1871, the <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Art_Institute" title="San Francisco Art Institute">San Francisco Art Institute</a> is the oldest <a href="/wiki/Art_school" title="Art school">art school</a> west of the Mississippi.<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[210]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/California_College_of_the_Arts" title="California College of the Arts">California College of the Arts</a>, located north of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Potrero_Hill,_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Potrero Hill, San Francisco (page does not exist)">Potrero Hill</a>, has programs in architecture, fine arts, design, and writing.<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">[211]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Conservatory_of_Music" title="San Francisco Conservatory of Music">San Francisco Conservatory of Music</a>, the only independent <a href="/w/index.php?title=Music_school&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Music school (page does not exist)">music school</a> on the West Coast, grants degrees in orchestral instruments, chamber music, composition, and conducting. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=California_Culinary_Academy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="California Culinary Academy (page does not exist)">California Culinary Academy</a>, associated with the <a href="/wiki/Le_Cordon_Bleu" title="Le Cordon Bleu">Le Cordon Bleu</a> program, offers programs in the culinary arts, baking and pastry arts, and hospitality and restaurant management.
<a href="/wiki/California_Institute_of_Integral_Studies" title="California Institute of Integral Studies">California Institute of Integral Studies</a>, founded in 1968, offers a variety of graduate programs in its Schools of Professional Psychology &amp; Health, and Consciousness and Transformation. Known for combining spirituality and social change, the Institute also features a bachelor's degree completion program.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Primary_and_secondary_schools">Primary and secondary schools</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Public_school_(government_funded)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Public school (government funded) (page does not exist)">Public schools</a> are run by the <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Unified_School_District" title="San Francisco Unified School District">San Francisco Unified School District</a> as well as the State Board of Education for some charter schools. <a href="/wiki/Lowell_High_School_(San_Francisco)" title="Lowell High School (San Francisco)">Lowell High School</a>, the oldest public high school in the U.S. west of the Mississippi,<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[212]</a></sup> and the smaller <a href="/w/index.php?title=School_of_the_Arts_High_School_(San_Francisco)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="School of the Arts High School (San Francisco) (page does not exist)">School of the Arts High School</a> are two of San Francisco's <a href="/wiki/Magnet_school" title="Magnet school">magnet schools</a> at the secondary level. Just under 30% of the city's school-age population attends one of San Francisco's more than 100 <a href="/wiki/Private_school" title="Private school">private</a> or <a href="/wiki/Parochial_school" title="Parochial school">parochial schools</a>, compared to a 10% rate nationwide.<sup id="cite_ref-SFGPrvtSchools_213-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SFGPrvtSchools-213">[213]</a></sup> Nearly 40 of those schools are <a href="/wiki/Catholic_school" title="Catholic school">Catholic schools</a> managed by the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Archdiocese_of_San_Francisco" title="Roman Catholic Archdiocese of San Francisco">Archdiocese of San Francisco</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">[214]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Transportation">Transportation</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Freeways_and_roads">Freeways and roads</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Due to its unique geography, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Freeway_and_expressway_revolts&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Freeway and expressway revolts (page does not exist)">freeway revolts</a> of the late 1950s,<sup id="cite_ref-freeway_215-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-freeway-215">[215]</a></sup> San Francisco is one of the few American cities with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Arterial_thoroughfares&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Arterial thoroughfares (page does not exist)">arterial thoroughfares</a> instead of having numerous highways within the city.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:San_Francisco_Oakland_Bay_Bridge_at_night.jpg" title="File:San Francisco Oakland Bay Bridge at night.jpg">File:San Francisco Oakland Bay Bridge at night.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/w/index.php?title=San_Francisco_%E2%80%93_Oakland_Bay_Bridge&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San Francisco – Oakland Bay Bridge (page does not exist)">Bay Bridge</a> offers the only direct automobile connection to the East Bay.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Interstate_80_in_California&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Interstate 80 in California (page does not exist)">Interstate 80</a> begins at the approach to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=San_Francisco_%E2%80%93_Oakland_Bay_Bridge&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San Francisco – Oakland Bay Bridge (page does not exist)">Bay Bridge</a> and is the only direct automobile link to the East Bay. <a href="/w/index.php?title=U.S._Route_101_in_California&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="U.S. Route 101 in California (page does not exist)">U.S. Route 101</a> connects to the western terminus of Interstate 80 and provides access to the south of the city along San Francisco Bay toward <a href="/wiki/Silicon_Valley" title="Silicon Valley">Silicon Valley</a>. Northbound, the routing for U.S. 101 uses arterial streets <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mission_Street_(San_Francisco)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mission Street (San Francisco) (page does not exist)">Mission Street</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Van_Ness_Avenue_(San_Francisco)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Van Ness Avenue (San Francisco) (page does not exist)">Van Ness Avenue</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lombard_Street_(San_Francisco)" title="Lombard Street (San Francisco)">Lombard Street</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Richardson_Avenue_(San_Francisco)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Richardson Avenue (San Francisco) (page does not exist)">Richardson Avenue</a>, and Doyle Drive to connect to the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Gate_Bridge" title="Golden Gate Bridge">Golden Gate Bridge</a>, the only direct automobile link to <a href="/wiki/Marin_County" title="Marin County" class="mw-redirect">Marin County</a> and the North Bay.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Golden_Gate_Bridge_1926.jpg" title="File:Golden Gate Bridge 1926.jpg">File:Golden Gate Bridge 1926.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Golden_Gate_Bridge" title="Golden Gate Bridge">Golden Gate Bridge</a> is the only road connection to the North Bay.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/California_State_Route_1" title="California State Route 1">State Route 1</a> also enters San Francisco from the north via the Golden Gate Bridge, but turns south away from the routing of U.S. 101, first onto Park Presidio Blvd through Golden Gate Park, and then bisecting the west side of the city as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=19th_Avenue_(San_Francisco)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="19th Avenue (San Francisco) (page does not exist)">19th Avenue</a> arterial thoroughfare, joining with <a href="/wiki/Interstate_280_(California)" title="Interstate 280 (California)">Interstate 280</a> at the city's southern border. Interstate 280 continues this southerly routing along the central portion of the Peninsula south to <a href="/wiki/San_Jose,_California" title="San Jose, California">San Jose</a>. Interstate 280 also turns to the east along the southern edge of the city, terminating just south of the Bay Bridge in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=South_of_Market_(San_Francisco)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="South of Market (San Francisco) (page does not exist)">South of Market</a> neighborhood. After the 1989 <a href="/wiki/Loma_Prieta_Earthquake" title="Loma Prieta Earthquake" class="mw-redirect">Loma Prieta Earthquake</a>, city leaders decided to demolish the <a href="/wiki/Embarcadero_Freeway" title="Embarcadero Freeway" class="mw-redirect">Embarcadero Freeway</a> as well, and voters approved demolition of a portion of the <a href="/wiki/Central_Freeway" title="Central Freeway">Central Freeway</a>, converting them into street-level boulevards.<sup id="cite_ref-freeway_215-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-freeway-215">[215]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/California_State_Route_35" title="California State Route 35">State Route 35</a>, which traverses the majority of the Peninsula along the ridge of the <a href="/wiki/Santa_Cruz_Mountains" title="Santa Cruz Mountains">Santa Cruz Mountains</a>, enters the city from the south as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Skyline_Boulevard&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Skyline Boulevard (page does not exist)">Skyline Boulevard</a>, following city streets until it terminates at its intersection with Highway 1. <a href="/wiki/California_State_Route_82" title="California State Route 82">State Route 82</a> enters San Francisco from the south as <a href="/wiki/Mission_Street" title="Mission Street">Mission Street</a>, following the path of the historic <a href="/wiki/El_Camino_Real_(California)" title="El Camino Real (California)">El Camino Real</a> and terminating shortly thereafter at its junction with 280.  Major east–west thoroughfares include <a href="/wiki/Geary_Boulevard" title="Geary Boulevard">Geary Boulevard</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_streets_in_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of streets in San Francisco (page does not exist)">Lincoln Way</a>/<a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_streets_in_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of streets in San Francisco (page does not exist)">Fell Street</a> corridor, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Market_Street_(San_Francisco)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Market Street (San Francisco) (page does not exist)">Market Street</a>/<a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_streets_in_San_Francisco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of streets in San Francisco (page does not exist)">Portola Drive</a>.
</p><p>The Western Terminus of the historic transcontinental <a href="/wiki/Lincoln_Highway" title="Lincoln Highway">Lincoln Highway</a>, the first road across America, is in San Francisco's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lincoln_Park_(San_Francisco)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lincoln Park (San Francisco) (page does not exist)">Lincoln Park</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Public_transportation">Public transportation</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:3_Cable_Car_on_Hyde_St_with_Alcatraz,_SF,_CA,_jjron_25.03.2012.jpg" title="File:3 Cable Car on Hyde St with Alcatraz, SF, CA, jjron 25.03.2012.jpg">File:3 Cable Car on Hyde St with Alcatraz, SF, CA, jjron 25.03.2012.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_cable_car_system" title="San Francisco cable car system">cable car</a> ascending Hyde St, with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alcatraz&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alcatraz (page does not exist)">Alcatraz</a> on the bay behind</div></div></div>
<p>32% of San Francisco residents use public transportation in daily commuting to work, ranking it first on the West Coast and third overall in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">[216]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Municipal_Railway" title="San Francisco Municipal Railway">San Francisco Municipal Railway</a>, known as Muni, is the primary public transit system of San Francisco. Muni is the seventh largest transit system in the United States, with 210,848,310 rides in 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">[217]</a></sup> The system operates both a combined light rail and subway system, the <a href="/wiki/Muni_Metro" title="Muni Metro">Muni Metro</a>, and a large bus network.<sup id="cite_ref-transportation_218-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-transportation-218">[218]</a></sup> Additionally, it runs a <a href="/w/index.php?title=F_Market&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="F Market (page does not exist)">historic streetcar line</a>, which runs on Market Street from <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Castro&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Castro (page does not exist)">Castro Street</a> to <a href="/wiki/Fisherman%27s_Wharf,_San_Francisco" title="Fisherman's Wharf, San Francisco">Fisherman's Wharf</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-transportation_218-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-transportation-218">[218]</a></sup> It also operates the famous <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_cable_car_system" title="San Francisco cable car system">cable cars</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-transportation_218-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-transportation-218">[218]</a></sup> which have been designated as a <a href="/wiki/National_Historic_Landmark" title="National Historic Landmark">National Historic Landmark</a> and are a major tourist attraction.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">[219]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Bay_Area_Rapid_Transit" title="Bay Area Rapid Transit">Bay Area Rapid Transit</a>, a regional Commuter Rail system, connects San Francisco with the <a href="/wiki/East_Bay_(San_Francisco_Bay_Area)" title="East Bay (San Francisco Bay Area)">East Bay</a> through the underwater <a href="/wiki/Transbay_Tube" title="Transbay Tube">Transbay Tube</a>. The line runs under Market Street to <a href="/wiki/Civic_Center,_San_Francisco" title="Civic Center, San Francisco">Civic Center</a> where it turns south to the Mission District, the southern part of the city, and through northern <a href="/wiki/San_Mateo_County,_California" title="San Mateo County, California">San Mateo County</a>, to the <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_International_Airport" title="San Francisco International Airport">San Francisco International Airport</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Millbrae,_California" title="Millbrae, California">Millbrae</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-transportation_218-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-transportation-218">[218]</a></sup>
Another Commuter Rail system, <a href="/wiki/Caltrain" title="Caltrain">Caltrain</a>, runs from San Francisco along the <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Peninsula" title="San Francisco Peninsula">San Francisco Peninsula</a> to <a href="/wiki/San_Jose,_California" title="San Jose, California">San Jose</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-transportation_218-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-transportation-218">[218]</a></sup> Historically, trains operated by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Southern_Pacific_Lines&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Southern Pacific Lines (page does not exist)">Southern Pacific Lines</a> ran from San Francisco to <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">Los Angeles</a>, via <a href="/wiki/Palo_Alto,_CA" title="Palo Alto, CA" class="mw-redirect">Palo Alto</a> and <a href="/wiki/San_Jose,_California" title="San Jose, California">San Jose</a>.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Transbay_Terminal" title="Transbay Terminal" class="mw-redirect">Transbay Terminal</a> serves as the terminus for long-range bus service (such as <a href="/wiki/Greyhound_Lines" title="Greyhound Lines">Greyhound</a>) and as a hub for regional bus systems <a href="/wiki/AC_Transit" title="AC Transit">AC Transit</a> (<a href="/wiki/Alameda_County,_California" title="Alameda County, California">Alameda</a> &amp; <a href="/wiki/Contra_Costa_County,_California" title="Contra Costa County, California">Contra Costa</a> counties), <a href="/wiki/WestCAT" title="WestCAT">WestCAT</a>, <a href="/wiki/SamTrans" title="SamTrans">SamTrans</a> (<a href="/wiki/San_Mateo_County,_California" title="San Mateo County, California">San Mateo County</a>), and <a href="/wiki/Golden_Gate_Transit" title="Golden Gate Transit">Golden Gate Transit</a> (Marin and <a href="/wiki/Sonoma_County,_California" title="Sonoma County, California">Sonoma Counties</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">[220]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Amtrak_California" title="Amtrak California">Amtrak California</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Thruway_Motorcoach&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Thruway Motorcoach (page does not exist)">Thruway Motorcoach</a> runs a shuttle bus from San Francisco to its <a href="/w/index.php?title=Emeryville_(Amtrak_station)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Emeryville (Amtrak station) (page does not exist)">rail station</a> across the Bay in <a href="/wiki/Emeryville,_California" title="Emeryville, California">Emeryville</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">[221]</a></sup> Lines from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Emeryville_(Amtrak_station)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Emeryville (Amtrak station) (page does not exist)">Emeryville Station</a> include the <a href="/wiki/Capitol_Corridor" title="Capitol Corridor">Capitol Corridor</a>, <a href="/wiki/San_Joaquin_(train)" title="San Joaquin (train)">San Joaquin</a>, <a href="/wiki/California_Zephyr" title="California Zephyr">California Zephyr</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Coast_Starlight" title="Coast Starlight">Coast Starlight</a>. Thruway service also runs south to <a href="/wiki/San_Luis_Obispo,_California" title="San Luis Obispo, California">San Luis Obispo, California</a> with connection to the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Surfliner" title="Pacific Surfliner">Pacific Surfliner</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:GGT_ferry_Del_Norte.JPG" title="File:GGT ferry Del Norte.JPG">File:GGT ferry Del Norte.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The Golden Gate Ferry <a href="/w/index.php?title=MV_Del_Norte&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="MV Del Norte (page does not exist)">M/V <i>Del Norte</i></a> docked at the Ferry Building.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Megabus_(North_America)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Megabus (North America) (page does not exist)">Megabus</a> recently relaunched intercity bus service in California and Nevada.<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[222]</a></sup> San Francisco riders can chose from three routes (SF-San Jose-LA, SF-Oakland-LA, &amp; SF-Sacramento-Reno). The San Francisco stop is located in front of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=San_Francisco_4th_and_King_Street_Station&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San Francisco 4th and King Street Station (page does not exist)">Caltrain Station</a>.  <a href="/w/index.php?title=BoltBus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BoltBus (page does not exist)">BoltBus</a> began service between the Bay Area and Los Angeles in October 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">[223]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=San_Francisco_Bay_Ferry&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San Francisco Bay Ferry (page does not exist)">San Francisco Bay Ferry</a> operates from the <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Ferry_Building" title="San Francisco Ferry Building">Ferry Building</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pier_39" title="Pier 39">Pier 39</a> to points in <a href="/wiki/Oakland,_California" title="Oakland, California">Oakland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alameda,_California" title="Alameda, California">Alameda</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bay_Farm_Island,_Alameda,_California&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bay Farm Island, Alameda, California (page does not exist)">Bay Farm Island</a>, <a href="/wiki/South_San_Francisco,_California" title="South San Francisco, California">South San Francisco</a>, and north to <a href="/wiki/Vallejo,_California" title="Vallejo, California">Vallejo</a> in <a href="/wiki/Solano_County,_California" title="Solano County, California">Solano County</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">[224]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Golden_Gate_Ferry&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Golden Gate Ferry (page does not exist)">Golden Gate Ferry</a> is the other ferry operator with service between San Francisco and <a href="/wiki/Marin_County" title="Marin County" class="mw-redirect">Marin County</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">[225]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Soltrans&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soltrans (page does not exist)">Soltrans</a> runs supplemental bus service between the Ferry Building and Vallejo.
</p><p>Cycling is a popular mode of transportation in San Francisco. 75,000 residents commute by bicycle per day.<sup id="cite_ref-2011_Bicycle_Count_Report_226-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011_Bicycle_Count_Report-226">[226]</a></sup>
</p><p>Pedestrian traffic is a major mode of transport. In 2011, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Walk_Score&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Walk Score (page does not exist)">Walk Score</a> ranked San Francisco the second most walkable city in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">[227]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">[228]</a></sup>
</p><p>San Francisco was an early adopter of <a href="/wiki/Carsharing" title="Carsharing">carsharing</a> in America. The non profit <a href="/w/index.php?title=City_Carshare&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="City Carshare (page does not exist)">City Carshare</a> opened in 2001.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">[229]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">[230]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Zipcar" title="Zipcar">Zipcar</a> closely followed.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bay_Area_Bike_Share&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bay Area Bike Share (page does not exist)">Bay Area Bike Share</a> launched in August 2013 with 700 bikes in downtown San Francisco and selected cities south to San Jose. The <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Municipal_Transportation_Agency" title="San Francisco Municipal Transportation Agency">San Francisco Municipal Transportation Agency</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bay_Area_Air_Quality_Management_District&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bay Area Air Quality Management District (page does not exist)">Bay Area Air Quality Management District</a> are responsible for the operation with management provided by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alta_Bicycle_Share&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alta Bicycle Share (page does not exist)">Alta Bicycle Share</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">[231]</a></sup> The system will be expanded in the future.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Airports">Airports</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:SFOApril2005.JPG" title="File:SFOApril2005.JPG">File:SFOApril2005.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">San Francisco International Airport (Located in San Mateo County but operated by San Francisco) is the primary airport of San Francisco and the San Francisco Bay Area.</div></div></div>
<p>Though located <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> south of downtown in unincorporated <a href="/wiki/San_Mateo_County,_California" title="San Mateo County, California">San Mateo County</a>, <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_International_Airport" title="San Francisco International Airport">San Francisco International Airport</a> (SFO) is under the jurisdiction of the City and County of San Francisco. SFO is a hub for <a href="/wiki/United_Airlines" title="United Airlines">United Airlines</a> <sup id="cite_ref-UAL_232-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UAL-232">[232]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Virgin_America" title="Virgin America">Virgin America</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-VirginAmerica_233-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VirginAmerica-233">[233]</a></sup> SFO is a major international gateway to Asia and Europe, with the largest international terminal in North America.<sup id="cite_ref-intlterminalfactsheet_234-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-intlterminalfactsheet-234">[234]</a></sup> In 2011, SFO was the 8th busiest airport in the U.S. and 22nd busiest in the world, handling over 40.9&#160;million passengers.<sup id="cite_ref-SFO-stats-2011_235-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SFO-stats-2011-235">[235]</a></sup>
</p><p>Located across the bay, <a href="/wiki/Oakland_International_Airport" title="Oakland International Airport">Oakland International Airport</a> is a popular, low-cost alternative to SFO. Geographically, Oakland Airport is approximately the same distance from downtown San Francisco as SFO, but due to its location across <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Bay" title="San Francisco Bay">San Francisco Bay</a>, it is greater driving distance from San Francisco.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Seaports">Seaports</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:FerryBuildingEmbarcaderoBayBridge.JPG" title="File:FerryBuildingEmbarcaderoBayBridge.JPG">File:FerryBuildingEmbarcaderoBayBridge.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Ferry_Building" title="San Francisco Ferry Building">Ferry Building</a> along the <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Embarcadero_(San_Francisco)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Embarcadero (San Francisco) (page does not exist)">Embarcadero</a></div></div></div>
<p>The Port of San Francisco was once the largest and busiest seaport on the West Coast. It featured rows of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Piers&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Piers (page does not exist)">piers</a> perpendicular to the shore, where cargo from the moored ships was handled by cranes and manual labor and transported to nearby warehouses. The port handled cargo to and from trans-Pacific and Atlantic destinations, and was the West Coast center of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=West_coast_lumber_trade&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="West coast lumber trade (page does not exist)">lumber trade</a>. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=1934_West_Coast_Longshore_Strike&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="1934 West Coast Longshore Strike (page does not exist)">1934 West Coast Longshore Strike</a>, an important episode in the history of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Labor_unions_in_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Labor unions in the United States (page does not exist)">American labor movement</a>, brought most ports to a standstill. The advent of <a href="/wiki/Container_shipping" title="Container shipping" class="mw-redirect">container shipping</a> made pier-based ports obsolete, and most commercial berths moved to the <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Oakland" title="Port of Oakland">Port of Oakland</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Port_of_Richmond_(California)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Port of Richmond (California) (page does not exist)">Port of Richmond</a>. A few active berths specializing in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Break_bulk_cargo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Break bulk cargo (page does not exist)">break bulk cargo</a> remain alongside the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Islais_Creek&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Islais Creek (page does not exist)">Islais Creek</a> Channel.
</p><p>Many piers remained derelict for years until the demolition of the <a href="/wiki/Embarcadero_Freeway" title="Embarcadero Freeway" class="mw-redirect">Embarcadero Freeway</a> reopened the downtown waterfront, allowing for redevelopment. The centerpiece of the port, the <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Ferry_Building" title="San Francisco Ferry Building">Ferry Building</a>, while still receiving commuter ferry traffic, has been restored and redeveloped as a gourmet marketplace. The port's other activities now focus on developing waterside assets to support recreation and tourism.
</p><p>The port currently uses Pier 35 to handle the 60-80 <a href="/wiki/Cruise_ship" title="Cruise ship">cruise ship</a> calls and 200,000 passengers that come to San Francisco.<sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">[236]</a></sup> Itineraries from San Francisco usually include round trip cruises to Alaska and Mexico. The new James R. Herman Cruise Terminal Project at Pier 27 is scheduled to open 2014 as a replacement. The existing primary terminal at Pier 35 has neither the sufficient capacity to allow for the increasing length and passenger capacity of new cruise ships nor the amenities needed for an international cruise terminal.<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">[237]</a></sup>
</p><p>On March 16, 2013, <a href="/wiki/Princess_Cruises" title="Princess Cruises">Princess Cruises</a> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Grand_Princess&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Grand Princess (page does not exist)">Grand Princess</a></i> became the first ship to home port in San Francisco year round. The ship offers cruises to Alaska, California Coasts, Hawaii, and Mexico.<i> Grand Princess </i> will be stationed in San Francisco until April 2014. Princess will also operate other ships during the summer of 2014, making it the only cruise line home porting year round in San Francisco.<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">[238]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Safety">Safety</span></h3>
<p>San Francisco has significantly higher rates of pedestrian and bicyclist traffic deaths than the USA on average. In 2013, 21 pedestrians were killed in vehicle collisions, the highest since 2001,<sup id="cite_ref-SF_Examiner_ped_safety_239-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SF_Examiner_ped_safety-239">[239]</a></sup> which is 2.5 deaths per 100,000 population - 70% higher than the national average of 1.5 deaths per 100,000 population.<sup id="cite_ref-NHTSA_2012_Crashes_240-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NHTSA_2012_Crashes-240">[240]</a></sup>  Four bicyclists were killed in vehicle collisions in 2013,<sup id="cite_ref-SF_Examiner_ped_safety_239-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SF_Examiner_ped_safety-239">[239]</a></sup> a rate twice as high as the national average of 0.23 deaths per 100,000 population.<sup id="cite_ref-NHTSA_2012_Crashes_240-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NHTSA_2012_Crashes-240">[240]</a></sup> On January 14, 2014, Supervisor <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jane_Kim&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jane Kim (page does not exist)">Jane Kim</a> introduced Vision Zero, a proposal to eliminate all traffic fatalities in San Francisco by 2024.<sup id="cite_ref-SF_Examiner_ped_safety_239-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SF_Examiner_ped_safety-239">[239]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Consulates_and_sister_cities">Consulates and sister cities</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
San Francisco participates in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sister_Cities_International&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sister Cities International (page does not exist)">Sister Cities</a> program.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">[241]</a></sup> A total of 41 consulates general and 23 honorary consulates have offices in the San Francisco Bay Area.<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">[242]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>
<p>{{#invoke:Portal|portal}}
</p>

</li>

</li>
</ul>

<ul>

</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cite_book&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cite book (page does not exist)">Template:Cite book</a>

</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cite_book&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cite book (page does not exist)">Template:Cite book</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cite_book&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cite book (page does not exist)">Template:Cite book</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cite_book&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cite book (page does not exist)">Template:Cite book</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cite_book&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cite book (page does not exist)">Template:Cite book</a>
</li>
<li> Solnit, Rebecca. <i>Infinite City: A San Francisco Atlas</i> (University of California Press, 2010). 144 pp.&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780520262508" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 978-0-520-26250-8</a>; <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.h-net.org/reviews/showrev.php?id=34658">online review</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cite_book&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cite book (page does not exist)">Template:Cite book</a>
</li>
<li> Winfield, P.H., <i>The Charter of San Francisco</i> (The fortnightly review Vol. 157–58:2 (1945), p.&#160;69–75)
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://cprr.org/Museum/SF_Overland_Monthly_1870.html"><i>San Francisco</i> (article)</a> (1870) <i>The Overland Monthly</i>, January, 1870 Vol. 4, No. 1, pp.&#160;9–23. San Francisco: A. Roman &amp; Co., Publishers
</li>
</ul>
